title: Mishoe v. QHG
description: In this civil action, QHG of Lake City, Inc. appeals the award of $750,000 in actual damages and $1,250,000 in punitive damages in favor of Jenny C. Mishoe.  QHG alleges a new trial should be granted as a result of an improper closing argument and the circuit court's erroneous restriction of the scope of QHG's cross-examination of Mishoe.  Moreover, QHG argues the evidence does not support an award of punitive damages.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jenny C. Mishoe, Respondent,
v.
QHG of Lake City, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4027
Heard June 15, 2005 â€“ Filed October 3, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles E. Carpenter, Jr. and S. Elizabeth Brosnan, both of Columbia and Douglas C. Baxter, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Ronnie Alan Sabb and W. E. Jenkinson, III, both of Kingstree, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this civil action, QHG of Lake City, Inc. appeals the award of $750,000 in actual damages and $1,250,000 in punitive damages in favor of Jenny C. Mishoe.Â  QHG alleges a new trial should be granted as a result of an improper closing argument and the circuit courtâ€™s erroneous restriction of the scope of QHGâ€™s cross-examination of Mishoe.Â  Moreover, QHG argues the evidence does not support an award of punitive damages.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On June 3, 1998, Jenny C. Mishoe visited her grandmother at Carolinas Hospital System, a wholly owned facility of QHG of Lake City, Inc.Â  After the visit, Mishoe left the hospital via the emergency room exit and proceeded to her car across the horseshoe drive area in front of the emergency room doors.Â  While walking across the pavement near the emergency room exit, Mishoeâ€™s left foot got caught in a hole.Â  Mishoe suffered serious injuries to both her left ankle and right knee.Â  
QHG was required to perform regular, twice-yearly safety inspections of its premises to maintain its accreditation.Â  On July 1, 1997, the head of maintenance for the hospital, Edward McDonald, provided the hospital with a written report stating a hole existed in the pavement near the emergency room exit.Â  The hospital took no action to repair the hole or warn visitors and patients of the holeâ€™s existence.Â  
The matter proceeded to trial and the jury returned a verdict in Mishoeâ€™s favor in the amount of $750,000 actual damages and $1,250,000 punitive damages.Â  The jury found Mishoe ten percent comparatively negligent, and the circuit court reduced the actual damages accordingly.Â  QHG made a motion for a directed verdict and judgment notwithstanding the verdict on the issue of punitive damages, which the circuit court denied.Â  The circuit court also denied QHGâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Punitive Damages
QHG alleges the circuit court erred in denying its motion for a directed verdict and judgment not withstanding the verdict on the issue of punitive damages.[1]Â  Specifically, QHG argues the circuit court erred because there was no clear and convincing evidence the hospitalâ€™s actions constituted willful, wanton, or reckless conduct.Â  We disagree.
In reviewing the denial of a motion for directed verdict or JNOV, the appellate court applies the same standard as the circuit court.Â  Gilliland v. Doe, 357 S.C. 197, 199, 592 S.E.2d 626, 627 (2004).Â  When ruling on directed verdict or JNOV motions, the circuit court must view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  If the evidence as a whole is susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should be denied.Â  Adams v. G.J. Creel & Sons, Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995).
On appeal from the denial of a motion for directed verdict or JNOV, the appellate court may only reverse if there is no evidence to support the circuit courtâ€™s ruling.Â  South Carolina Prop. & Cas. Guar. Assâ€™n v. Yessen, 345 S.C. 512, 521, 548 S.E.2d 880, 885 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Neither the circuit court nor the appellate court has the authority to decide credibility issues or resolve conflicts in testimony.Â  Garrett v. Locke, 309 S.C. 94, 99, 419 S.E.2d 842, 845 (Ct. App. 1992).
In order to receive an award of punitive damages, the plaintiff has the burden of proving by clear and convincing evidence the defendantâ€™s misconduct was willful, wanton, or with reckless disregard for the plaintiffâ€™s rights.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-33-135 (2004); Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 221, 479 S.E.2d 35, 46 (1996).Â  A conscious failure to exercise due care constitutes willfulness.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 301, 536 S.E.2d 408, 419 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  When evidence exists that suggests a defendant is aware of a dangerous condition and does not take action to minimize or avoid the danger, sufficient evidence exists to create a jury issue as to whether there is clear and convincing evidence of willfulness.Â  See McGee v. Bruce Hosp. Sys., 321 S.C. 340, 346, 468 S.E.2d 633, 637 (1996).Â  The issue of punitive damages must be submitted to the jury if more than one reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence as to whether the defendantâ€™s behavior was reckless, willful, or wanton.Â  Welch, 342 S.C. at 301, 536 S.E.2d at 419.Â  
The amount of damages, actual or punitive, remains largely within the discretion of the finder of fact, as reviewed by the trial judge.Â  Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 406 S.E.2d 350 (1991).Â  The trial judge is vested with considerable discretion over the amount of a punitive damages award, and this courtâ€™s review is limited to correction of errors of law.Â  Welch, 342 S.C. at 305, 536 S.E.2d at 421.Â  Moreover, the appellate court must affirm the circuit courtâ€™s punitive damages finding if any evidence reasonably supports the courtâ€™s factual findings.Â  Austin v. Specialty Transp. Servs., Inc., 358 S.C. 298, 314, 594 S.E.2d 867, 875 (Ct. App. 2004). 
Here, the evidence demonstrates the head of maintenance for QHG provided actual, written notice of the existence of the hole in question to the CEO of the hospital on July 1, 1997, almost one year before the accident occurred.Â  QHG took no action to repair the hole after receiving notice of its existence.Â  Moreover, the hospital took no precautions to warn visitors or patients of the existence of the hole.Â  Therefore, we find the evidence of this written notice is sufficient to submit the issue of QHGâ€™s willful, wanton, reckless, or malicious conduct to the jury.
II.Â  Mistrial Motion
QHG next argues the circuit court erred in failing to grant its motion for a mistrial.Â  QHG alleges comments made by Mishoe during closing arguments could not be remedied by the circuit courtâ€™s curative instruction and, therefore, a mistrial was warranted.Â  Specifically, QHG claims any reference to the $2.8 million sales price of the hospital resulted in sufficient prejudice to justify a mistrial.Â  We disagree.
The granting or denying of a motion for mistrial is within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Creighton v. Coligny Plaza Ltd. Partnership, 334 S.C. 96, 118, 512 S.E.2d 510, 521 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Absent an abuse of discretion, the decision of the trial judge will not be overturned on appeal.Â  Id.Â  The burden is on the moving party to show not only error, but also the resulting prejudice.Â  Id.Â  The granting of a motion for a mistrial is an extreme measure which should be taken only when an incident is so grievous that the prejudicial effect can be removed in no other way.Â  State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 310, 513 S.E.2d 606, 610 (1999).
When an objection is timely made to improper remarks of counsel during closing arguments, the judge should rule on the objection, give a curative charge to the jury, and instruct offending counsel to desist from improper remarks.Â  McElveen v. Ferre, 299 S.C. 377, 381, 385 S.E.2d 39, 41 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  In this matter, counsel for Mishoe made the following remarks to the jury on the issue of punitive damages:

What is the reasonable relationship to harm-and there was harm-and the defendantâ€™s ability to pay.Â  [sic]Â  I ainâ€™t too much worried about that hospital paying.Â  When they left Williamsburg County, they left with 2.8 million dollars worth of our money just when they left.

At that time, counsel for QHG objected, and stated:

QHG: Your Honor, Iâ€™d object to any testimony about how much money the hospital sold for, and everybody knows-
The Court: The objection is-
QHG: -the price of the deal
The Court: Yes, sir.
QHG:Â  And I would move for a mistrial.
The Court:Â  Pardon?
QHG: Iâ€™d move for a mistrial.
The Court:Â  Ladies and gentlemen, the objection is sustained and you are to disregard the last argument by counsel.Â  And, counsel, you are not to argue that particular issue.Â  The motion is otherwise denied.

After the curative instruction was given, no additional objection was made by
QHG.  
The circuit court followed the procedure established in McElveen.Â  The judge ruled on QHGâ€™s objection, offered a curative instruction to the jury, and admonished Mishoeâ€™s counsel not to mention the sales price and the fact it was â€œour moneyâ€ again.Â  See McElveen, 299 S.C. at 381, 385 S.E.2d at 41.Â  The curative instruction adequately corrected the statement and advised the jury to disregard.Â  Moreover, the sales price of the hospital had already been admitted, and the jury heard the amount during the trial.Â  QHG cannot demonstrate evidence of a prejudicial effect warranting a mistrial.Â  See Creighton, 334 S.C. at 118, 512 S.E.2d at 521.Â  Therefore, we find the trial judge did not abuse his broad discretion in denying the mistrial motion.Â  
III.Â  Scope of cross-examination
QHG also argues the trial court erred in limiting the scope of its cross-examination of Mishoe.Â  Specifically, QHG asserts the circuit court erred in prohibiting it from questioning Mishoe on her prior litigation history as it was relevant to her credibility.Â  We disagree.
The admission and rejection of testimony is largely within the trial judgeâ€™s sound discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent a showing that the trial court abused its discretion or its decision was controlled by an error of law.Â  Ippolito v. Hospitality Mgt. Assocs., 352 S.C. 563, 569, 575 S.E.2d 562, 566 (Ct. App. 2003).
In this case, QHG argues the medical records of Dr. Hazelwood, a treating physician, are important to prove that Mishoeâ€™s medical condition had nothing to do with the fall at the hospital.Â  The trial judge allowed QHG to introduce the majority of the medical records of Dr. Hazelwood.Â  The trial judge allowed into evidence the portion of the records relevant to QHGâ€™s argument.Â  The evidence in those records was relevant to the issue of whether Mishoe sought treatment from Dr. Hazelwood for injuries unrelated to the fall at the hospital was admitted.Â  The only sentence the trial judge did not admit was Dr. Mendes â€œrefused to see her again because of her prior experience with litigation.â€Â  The trial judge allowed QHG to cross-examine Mishoe on her relevant medical history.Â  Therefore, we hold the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in limiting the scope of the cross-examination.
CONCLUSION
For the aforementioned reasons, the decision of the circuit court and award of punitive damages is hereby
 AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] QHG does not ask this court to review the circuit courtâ€™s Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 406 S.E.2d 350 (1991), punitive damages analysis.Â  Although QHG takes issue with opposing counselâ€™s comment during closing argument regarding the $2.8 million sale of the hospital, it does so only by arguing a mistrial should have been granted.Â  See infra.Â  QHG does not assert the use of the $2.8 million sales price was an improper method to value QHGâ€™s net worth.

title: Armstrong v. Collins
description: Fred Collins appeals from a jury award in favor of Marshall Armstrong on causes of action for fraud, constructive fraud, negligent misrepresentation, breach of fiduciary duty, breach of contract, and breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.  Collins argues the trail court erred in:  (1) failing to direct a verdict as to all causes of action; (2) allowing Armstrong to amend his complaint to include the two breach of contract causes of action; and (3) failing to grant Collins a continuance based upon the late amendment.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Marshall Armstrong, Respondent,
v.
Fred Collins, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4028
Heard May 11, 2005 â€“ Filed October 3, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles E. Carpenter, Jr. and S. Elizabeth Brosnan, both of Columbia and Melvin Hutson and Lynn R. Hudson, both of Greenville, for Appellant.
James Richardson and Richard A. Harpootlian, both of Columbia and Richard J. Breibart, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Fred Collins, Jr., appeals from a jury award in favor of Marshall Armstrong on causes of action for fraud, constructive fraud, negligent misrepresentation, breach of fiduciary duty, breach of contract, and breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.Â  Collins argues the trial court erred in: (1) failing to direct a verdict as to all causes of action; (2) allowing Armstrong to amend his complaint to include the two breach of contract claims; and (3) failing to grant Collins a continuance based on the late amendment.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
Collins is the sole owner of Collins Entertainment, Inc., a conglomerate that owns and operates video games.Â  Armstrong began working for Collins Entertainment in 1980, and he became president of the corporation in charge of day-to-day operations in 1998.Â  Armstrong and Collins became friends, and prior to the litigation, Collins included Armstrong as a beneficiary under his will.Â  
During the 1990s, video poker machines yielded Collins Entertainment gross annual revenues of about $63 million and net profits of $12 or $13 million per year.Â  Video poker was Collins Entertainmentâ€™s core product, from which it derived eighty percent of its gross revenues.Â  In the early 1990s, Collins Entertainment borrowed $12 million from SouthTrust Bank to finance a public stock offering.Â  SouthTrust secured its loan by taking a security interest in all of Collins Entertainmentâ€™s business assets.[1]Â  However, when cash payouts for video poker were outlawed effective July 1, 2000, Collins Entertainment was left without its most profitable product.Â  See Joytime Distribs. & Amusement Co. v. State, 338 S.C. 634, 650, 528 S.E.2d 647, 655 (1999) (upholding the portion of the legislative act banning cash payouts effective July 1, 2000).Â  Collins Entertainment owed SouthTrust somewhere between $13 and $20 million in principal and interest.Â  
During this period, an idea was developed to alter old, existing bingo machines such that they could generate additional revenue.Â  Armstrong testified that he came up with the idea when he noticed that the supreme courtâ€™s opinion in Joytime excluded Class III Bingo machines.Â  Although the licensing fee for Class III Bingo machines was $2000 per year, Armstrong discovered that older machines could be modified and licensed under a different class that had only a $100 per year licensing fee.Â  
Armstrong testified that he discussed his idea with Collins, who was unconvinced at first.Â  Collins allowed Armstrong to use some old machines that Collins owned personally to construct working models.Â  Armstrong worked on the project during hours that he was not working for Collins Entertainment.Â  Armstrong stated that he made four modifications to the machines, including adding an electronic circuit board, a flipper to bring the machine within the â€œgame of skillâ€ requirement for the lower licensing fee, and a printer to print tickets showing credits won which would be redeemable for merchandise.Â  Armstrong applied for a patent for the new Skillpins machine.Â Â  
Armstrong was interested in going into business for himself and wanted to work about fourteen more years before retirement.Â  Because Collins Entertainment was so heavily laden with debt, Armstrong testified that Collins proposed that a separate entity be created to market the Skillpins machines.Â  The new corporation would be ninety percent owned by Collins and ten percent owned by Armstrong.Â  Armstrong would also be guaranteed a salary of $150,000 a year.Â  Armstrong would later resign from Collins Entertainment and run the new corporation.Â  Additionally, Armstrong testified that Collins agreed to personally borrow $1,000,000 from the bank, with Armstrong co-signing, to fund the endeavor.Â  The agreement, however, was never reduced to writing.Â  
Collins instructed Armstrong to go to Europe to secure exclusive distribution agreements for the new venture, later called Skillpins, Inc.Â  The trips were successful, resulting in agreements with G.A.A., Seeben, and Splin S.A.Â  The agreements were executed in the Skillpins name, as instructed by Collins.Â  Skillpins was to use separate contracts, delivery slips, and work slips.Â  Collins Entertainment paid for the trips, but Skillpins was to reimburse Collins Entertainment once it became profitable.Â  Employees of Collins Entertainment also accompanied Armstrong on the trip.Â  Dennis Cosentino, one of the employees who traveled with Armstrong, testified that during the trip, Armstrong was the most excited he had seen him in twenty years because Armstrong was going to be a part owner.Â  Armstrong testified that he would not have made these trips but for the promise of part ownership.Â Â  
When the corporation later began operating, separate contracts were employed for Skillpins machines, even if Collins Entertainment machines were already operating at the location.Â  Collins had never previously created a corporation for a specific product in South Carolina.Â  Armstrong continued to work on the Skillpins project during hours he was not working for Collins Entertainment, and he executed agreements using the Skillpins name.Â  
Tim Youmans, an attorney working for Collins Entertainment and later for Armstrong, testified that Collins told him that he had decided to give Armstrong ten percent of the new corporation that was to be separate and unencumbered by the SouthTrust debt.Â  According to both Youmans and Armstrong, Collins instructed Youmans to find a shell corporation owned by Collins personally that was not encumbered with the SouthTrust debt.Â  Youmans found a corporation meeting the criteria, and the corporationâ€™s name was changed to Skillpins, Inc.Â  On the same date, another corporation under the Collins Entertainment umbrella was renamed Skill Flippers, LLC.Â  This entity was to be the distribution vehicle for Skillpins, Inc.Â  However, it was never used for that purpose.Â  
The agreement between Armstrong and Collins was to be reduced to writing later by Richard Cox, an outside attorney for Collins Entertainment.Â  Eventually, Armstrong and Collins met with Cox.Â  According to Armstrong, Collins informed Cox that Skillpins was to be an entity completely separate from Collins Entertainment, that Armstrong would own ten percent of the corporation, and that Collins wanted to be a silent partner.Â  Cox testified that the partiesâ€™ intent was to set up an independent entity with each having an ownership position.Â  Collins gave Armstrong constant assurances that the paperwork would soon be generated.Â  Cox never prepared the documents.Â Â Â  
Collins held a meeting at Collins Entertainment with upper level management and he discussed Skillpins.Â  Armstrongâ€™s recollection of the meeting was that Collins informed the other employees that Skillpins was Armstrongâ€™s idea, and that a separate corporation was to be formed of which Armstrong would own ten percent.Â  Collins recalled stating that he had offered Armstrong ten percent of Collins Entertainment, not ten percent of Skillpins.Â  
By November of 2000, two or three hundred Skillpins machines were operating and producing income.[2]Â  At that time, Armstrong discovered information concerning Skillpins was included in Collins Entertainmentâ€™s profit and loss statement.Â  Armstrong confronted Collins, and Collins confirmed that Skillpins had been brought under the Collins Entertainment umbrella.Â  Collins offered Armstrong ten percent of Collins Entertainment.Â  Armstrong refused, saying he did not want ten percent of the $13 to $20 million debt.Â  Collins laughed and said he did not think Armstrong would.Â  Armstrong immediately resigned.Â Â  
Skillpins, Inc., purchased all the Skillpins machines.Â  However, Collins Entertainment paid for the machines and booked all the machines as Collins Entertainment assets.Â  Collins Entertainment started another patent application, listing Collins and his son as the inventors.Â  This application was never filed.Â  Within thirty days after litigation ensued, Skillpins, Inc. was dissolved.Â  In 2001, Skillpins machines generated sixty-seven and one-half percent of Collins Entertainmentâ€™s revenues.Â Â Â  
After Armstrong resigned, he formed his own corporation with Youmans as a minority shareholder.Â  At the time of the hearing, Armstrongâ€™s corporation operated about 250 Skillpins machines and over 100 video redemption games.Â  However, Armstrongâ€™s declining health forced him to stop working full-time after January of 2001.Â Â Â  
Armstrong brought an action against Collins alleging fraud, constructive fraud, negligent misrepresentation, breach of fiduciary duty, and violation of South Carolinaâ€™s Unfair Trade Practices Act, and the case was tried before a jury.Â  In his opening statement, counsel for Armstrong stated that the case was â€œabout whether or not there was a contract between Fred Collins and Marshall Armstrong.â€Â  Counsel further stated that the question for the jury was whether they had a meeting of the minds.Â  However, counsel for Collins later objected to admission of evidence of the financial success of video poker in part on the ground that no breach of contract had been alleged in this case.Â Â  
At the close of Armstrongâ€™s case, he moved to amend the complaint to add causes of action for breach of contract and breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, arguing that the existence of a contract was implicit in the factual basis for the case.Â  Counsel for Collins objected on the ground that they were unable to conduct discovery and cross-examine witnesses with these causes of action in mind.Â  The court granted the amendment, finding no prejudice because the existence of a contract was an integral part of the case.Â  However, the court allowed defense counsel to recall Armstrong for further cross-examination.Â  Collins then moved for a continuance or adjournment, which was denied.Â  Later, Collins testified on direct that he and Armstrong â€œnever had a meeting of the mindsâ€ and that their agreement never got past â€œstep two.â€Â Â  
Armstrong then rested, and Collins immediately moved for a directed verdict on all causes of action.Â  The trial court granted the motion with respect to the unfair trade practices cause of action but denied the motion on all other causes of action.Â  At the close of the evidence and again after the verdict, defense counsel renewed the motion, and the trial judge reiterated its prior ruling.Â Â Â  
The case was submitted to a jury on a special verdict form.Â  The jury found for Armstrong on all six causes of action, awarding $300,000 for each cause of action.Â  The jury also awarded $1.2 million in punitive damages.Â  When asked by the trial court for clarification of the verdict, the foreperson responded that the jury calculated actual damages of over $1.7 million and rounded up to $1.8 million.Â  They then simply divided the total by six, intending to find for the plaintiff on all causes of action.Â  Without objection, the court enrolled the actual damages as a general verdict for $1.8 million.Â Â  The court denied all of Collinsâ€™ other motions.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn ruling on directed verdict or JNOV motions, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions.â€Â  Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  The trial court is only concerned with the â€œexistence or nonexistence of evidence.â€Â  Long v. Norris & Assocs., 342 S.C. 561, 568, 538 S.E.2d 5, 9 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œWhen the evidence yields only one inference, a directed verdict in favor of the moving party is proper.â€Â  Id.Â  However, â€œif more than one reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence, the case must be submitted to the jury.â€Â  Id.Â  On appeal from the denial of a motion for a directed verdict or JNOV, this court will reverse the trial court only when there is no evidence to support the ruling.Â  Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife & Marine Res. Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 29, 491 S.E.2d 571, 573 (1997). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Directed Verdict 
Collins argues the trial court erred by failing to grant him a directed verdict because Armstrong failed to prove all the necessary elements for each of the six causes of action that went to the jury.Â  Collins also argues that he should have been granted a directed verdict because the alleged agreement was unenforceable.Â  Collins asserts the parties could not legally have entered into a contract that would deprive SouthTrust Bank of its security interest.Â  We address each of these arguments below.Â Â Â  
A. Fraud/Constructive Fraud/Negligent Misrepresentation
Collins argues that Armstrong failed to produce evidence to support fraud, constructive fraud, and negligent misrepresentation because Armstrong had no right to rely upon representations that Skillpins would be separate from Collins Entertainment.Â  Collins argues that any such representation would have been inconsistent with knowledge Armstrong, as president of Collins Entertainment, would have gained regarding the SouthTrust Bank loan.Â  We disagree. 
To sustain a claim of fraud, all of the following elements must be proven:

(1) a representation; (2) its falsity; (3) its materiality; (4) either knowledge of its falsity or reckless disregard of its truth or falsity; (5) intent that the representation be acted upon; (6) the hearerâ€™s ignorance of its falsity; (7) the hearerâ€™s reliance on its truth; (8) the hearerâ€™s right to rely thereon; and (9) the hearerâ€™s consequent and proximate injury.Â  

Regions Bank v. Schmuch, 354 S.C. 648, 672, 582 S.E.2d 432, 444-45 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œThe right to rely must be determined in light of the plaintiffâ€™s duty to use reasonable prudence and diligence under the circumstances in identifying the truth with respect to the representations made to him.â€Â  Id. at 672, 582 S.E.2d at 445.Â  Fraud must be shown by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Ardis v. Cox, 314 S.C. 512, 515, 431 S.E.2d 267, 269 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  A party may not rely upon a misstatement of fact when the truth is easily within his reach.Â  King v. Oxford, 282 S.C. 307, 312, 318 S.E.2d 125, 128 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  â€œIt is the policy of the courts not only to discourage fraud, but also to discourage negligence and inattention to oneâ€™s own interests.â€Â 
Id.Â  However, a party may rely on representations without making further inquiry when a fiduciary or confidential relationship exists between the parties.Â  Epstein v. Howell, 308 S.C. 528, 530-31, 419 S.E.2d 379, 380-82 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  
â€œâ€˜To establish constructive fraud, all elements of actual fraud except the element of intent must be established.â€™â€Â  Pitts v. Jackson Natâ€™l Life Ins. Co., 352 S.C. 319, 333, 574 S.E.2d 502, 509 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Ardis v. Cox, 314 S.C. 512, 515, 431 S.E.2d 267, 269 (Ct. App. 1993)).Â  â€œNeither actual dishonesty of purpose nor intent to deceive is an essential element of constructive fraud while intent to deceive is an essential element of actual fraud.â€Â  Ardis, 314 S.C. at 516, 431 S.E.2d at 269-70.Â  Actual fraud is distinguished from constructive fraud by the presence or absence of the intent to deceive.Â  Pitts, 352 S.C. at 334, 574 S.E.2d at 509.Â  â€œHowever, in a constructive fraud case, where there is no confidential or fiduciary relationship, and an armâ€™s length transaction between mature, educated people is involved, there is no right to rely.â€Â  Ardis, 314 S.C. at 516, 431 S.E.2d at 270.Â  
In a negligent misrepresentation action, a plaintiff must prove the following: 

(1) the defendant made a false representation to the plaintiff, (2) the defendant had a pecuniary interest in making the statement, (3) the defendant owed a duty of care to see that he communicated truthful information to the plaintiff, (4) the defendant breached that duty by failing to exercise due care, (5) the plaintiff justifiably relied on the representation, and (6) the plaintiff suffered a pecuniary loss as the proximate result of his reliance on the representation.Â  

Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 42, 557 S.E.2d 676, 680-81 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The key difference between fraud and negligent misrepresentation is that â€œfraud requires the conveyance of a known falsity, while negligent misrepresentation is predicated upon transmission of a negligently made false statement.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œA duty to exercise reasonable care in giving information exists when the defendant has a pecuniary interest in the transaction.â€Â  Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 474, 581 S.E.2d 496, 504 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œThe recovery of damages may be predicated upon a negligently made false statement where a party suffers either injury or loss as a consequence of relying upon the misrepresentation.â€Â  Winburn v. Ins. Co. of N. Am., 287 S.C. 435, 441, 339 S.E.2d 142, 146 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  A claim for negligent misrepresentation may be made when the misrepresented facts induced the plaintiff to enter a contract or business transaction.Â  Redwend, 354 S.C. at 474, 581 S.E.2d at 504.Â Â Â  
Each of the above causes of action contains the necessary element that the hearer had the right to rely upon the misrepresentation or fraud.Â  Collins argues that Armstrong had no right to rely on the promise that he would be part owner of a corporate entity separate from Collins Entertainment because he was imputed with knowledge of the SouthTrust Bank security interest in any potential new business due to his position as president of Collins Entertainment.Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Armstrong, we find there was sufficient evidence to submit these causes of action to the jury.Â  Armstrong testified that he was only in charge of day-to-day operations of Collins Entertainment, that he had no control over financial matters, and that he did not know what the SouthTrust Bank security agreement covered.Â  Collins, not Armstrong, was a signatory to the agreement with SouthTrust Bank.Â  Collins represented to Armstrong that he intended to create a new corporation, unencumbered by SouthTrustâ€™s security interest, in which Armstrong would have ten percent ownership.Â  Great care was taken to locate a corporate shell owned by Collins personally, not by Collins Entertainment, in order to create Skillpins as a separate entity.Â  Although some Collins Entertainment resources were used in sending Armstrong to Europe, there is evidence that Collins, as Armstrongâ€™s longtime friend, assured him that Skillpins would be separate from Collins Entertainment.Â  Further, evidence was presented that Collins intended to personally sign a loan for the startup money for Skillpins.Â  Thus, evidence existed that Armstrong had the right to rely upon Collinsâ€™ promises that Skillpins would be a separate entity.Â  
Because evidence existed to support the element of Armstrongâ€™s right to rely, the trial court correctly denied Collinsâ€™ motions for a directed verdict with regard to fraud, constructive fraud, and negligent misrepresentation.Â  The matter was appropriately sent to the jury.Â Â Â  
B. Breach of Fiduciary Duty
Collins asserts the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict as to Armstrongâ€™s cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty.Â  He maintains that no fiduciary relationship existed.Â  We disagree.Â  

â€œA confidential or fiduciary relationship exists when one imposes a special confidence in another, so that the latter, in equity and good conscience, is bound to act in good faith and with due regard to the interests of the one imposing the confidence.â€Â  Island Car Wash, Inc. v. Norris, 292 S.C. 595, 599, 358 S.E.2d 150, 152 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  A relationship must be more than casual to equal a fiduciary relationship.Â  Steele v. Victory Sav. Bank, 294 S.C. 290, 368 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œCourts of equity have carefully refrained from defining the particular instances of fiduciary relationship in such a manner that other and perhaps new cases might be excluded and have refused to set any bounds to the circumstances out of which a fiduciary relationship may spring.â€Â  Island Car Wash, Inc., 292 S.C. at 599, 358 S.E.2d at 152; see Burwell v. South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank, 288 S.C. 34, 41, 340 S.E.2d 786, 790 (1986) (â€œAs a general rule, mere respect for anotherâ€™s judgment or trust in his character is usually not sufficient to establish such a [fiduciary] relationship.Â  The facts and circumstances must indicate that one reposing the trust has foundation for his belief that the one giving advice or presenting arguments is acting not in his own behalf, but in the interests of the other party.â€).Â  

Pitts v. Jackson Natâ€™l Life Ins. Co., 352 S.C. 319, 330, 574 S.E.2d 502, 507 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Thus, to determine whether a fiduciary relationship existed, this court must look to the particulars of the relationship between the parties.Â  Id.
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Armstrong, there was sufficient evidence to send the cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty to the jury.Â  Evidence was presented at trial that Armstrong and Collins intended Skillpins to be a separate entity from Collins Entertainment.Â  Armstrong testified that Collins assured him that he would create a business entity that would be separate from Collins Entertainmentâ€™s debts.Â  Armstrong was entrusted to develop the Skillpins product, test it, and obtain manufacturers.Â  Thus, evidence existed that the parties had a special relationship, separate from Collins Entertainment, in which each entrusted the other to act in good faith and with due regard for the interests of the other.Â  Because evidence existed of a fiduciary relationship, the trial court properly denied Collinsâ€™ motion for a directed verdict.Â  
C. Breach of Contract Claims
Collins next argues that the trial court should have directed a verdict on Armstrongâ€™s claims for breach of contract and breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.Â  He argues Collins only promised to give Armstrong a gift in the future that did not amount to a contract.Â  Thus, he argues, there was no contract, and he was entitled to a directed verdict as to both contract causes of action.[3]Â  We disagree.Â  
The required elements of a contract are an offer, acceptance, and valuable consideration.Â  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 406, 581 S.E.2d 161, 166 (2003). Â â€œA contract is an obligation which arises from actual agreement of the parties manifested by words, oral or written, or by conduct.â€Â  Roberts v. Gaskins, 327 S.C. 478, 483, 486 S.E.2d 771, 773 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Valuable consideration may consist of â€œsome right, interest, profit or benefit accruing to one party or some forbearance, detriment, loss or responsibility given, suffered or undertaken by the other.â€Â  Prestwick Golf Club, Inc. v. Prestwick Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 331 S.C. 385, 389, 503 S.E.2d 184, 186 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  A benefit to the promisor or a detriment to the promisee may provide sufficient consideration for a contract.Â  Shayne of Miami, Inc. v. Greybow, Inc., 232 S.C. 161, 167, 101 S.e.2d 486, 489 (1957).Â  If the evidence as to the existence of a contract is conflicting or raises more than one reasonable inference, the issue should be submitted to the jury.Â  Hendricks v. Clemson Univ., 353 S.C. 449, 459, 578 S.E.2d 711, 716 (2003).Â  With certain exceptions, a contract need not be in writing to be enforceable.Â  Gaskins v. Firemenâ€™s Ins. Co. of Newark, N.J., 206 S.C. 213, 216, 33 S.E.2d 498, 499 (1945) (noting that if there is a meeting of the minds with regard to the essential elements of a contract, it is immaterial whether the contract is written or oral).Â  
Having a contract is a prerequisite to proving breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.Â  To prove this cause of action, a plaintiff must show: (1) a breach of contract; (2) fraudulent intent relating to the breaching of the contract and not merely to its making; and (3) a fraudulent act accompanying the breach.Â  Floyd v. Country Squire Mobile Homes, Inc., 287 S.C. 51, 53-54, 336 S.E.2d 502, 503-04 (Ct. App. 1985).Â Â  â€œFraudulent intent is normally proved by circumstances surrounding the breach.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe fraudulent act may be prior to, contemporaneous with, or subsequent to the breach of contract, but it must be connected with the breach itself and cannot be too remote in either time or character.â€Â  Id. at 54, 336 S.E.2d at 504.Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Armstrong, we find there was evidence that a contract was formed and, thus, both contract causes of action were properly submitted to the jury.Â  Collins maintained that the parties never had a meeting of the minds and that the only offer he ever made Armstrong was for ten percent of Collins Entertainment.Â  However, Armstrong and Youmans both testified that Collins offered to create a new entity unencumbered by the SouthTrust debt and that Armstrong would be a ten percent owner.Â  Armstrong further testified that he accepted Collinsâ€™ offer and procured the exclusive distribution agreements in reliance on the agreement.Â  The consideration for Collins was his agreement to capitalize the new business entity.Â  Armstrongâ€™s consideration was his agreement to continue working for Collins Entertainment while developing the new Skillpins product on his own time, despite his desire to go into business for himself.Â  
Because the evidence conflicted, a jury question existed as to whether a contract was formed.Â  Thus, the trial court properly denied the motion for a directed verdict and sent the two contract causes of action to the jury. 
D. Unenforceability of Contract
Collins argues the trial court erred in failing to grant him a directed verdict as to all of Armstrongâ€™s causes of action because the alleged agreement was unenforceable.Â  He argues that he did not have the legal ability to enter into the alleged contract with Armstrong because any such agreement would unlawfully deprive SouthTrust Bank of its interest in its collateral.Â  We disagree.Â  
Generally, courts will not enforce contracts that are illegal or violate public policy.Â  See White v. J.M. Brown Amusement Co., Inc., 360 S.C. 366, 371, 601 S.E.2d 342, 345 (2004) (â€œThe general rule, well established in South Carolina, is that courts will not enforce a contract when the subject matter of the contract or an act required for performance violates public policy as expressed in constitutional provisions, statutory law, or judicial decisions.â€); see also Beach Co. v. Twillman, Ltd., 351 S.C. 56, 64, 566 S.E.2d 863, 866 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding that illegal contracts are void and unenforceable, such that actions for its breach may not be maintained).Â  However, we find this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  
In arguing for a directed verdict as to the three fraud causes of action, Collinsâ€™ counsel argued that Armstrong had no right to rely because â€œthe question of whether this could, in fact, be done was a serious questionâ€ in light of the bank obligations.Â  Although counsel argued that Armstrong had no right to rely because he should have inquired about the bank obligations, Collinsâ€™ counsel did not argue, as he does in his appellate brief, that the contract was illegal and unenforceable because it violated SouthTrust Bankâ€™s security agreement.Â  Because this argument was not presented to the trial court in support of Collinsâ€™ motion for a directed verdict, the court was never given the opportunity to rule upon whether the agreement was unenforceable.Â  Accordingly, the matter is not preserved and we decline to address it.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding that matters not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review).Â Â  
E. Failure to Prove Damages
Collins contends the trial court should have granted his motion for a directed verdict as to all causes of action because Armstrong failed to prove damages.Â  He argues that because Armstrong benefited from starting his own corporation after leaving Collins Entertainment, Armstrong cannot show that he sustained any damages from a breach of the alleged agreement.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note Collins only moved for a directed verdict for failure to prove damages as to the claims for fraud, constructive fraud, and negligent misrepresentation, arguing that Armstrong failed to prove Skillpins was profitable and that Armstrong would have suffered no change in salary.Â  Thus, the argument Collins raises on appeal regarding the benefit to Armstrong from any alleged breach was never presented to the trial court.Â  Further, Collins never raised any argument before the trial court with regard to damages as to the breach of contract and breach of contract with fraudulent intent causes of action.Â  Accordingly, Collinsâ€™ current argument on appeal is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Staubes, 339 S.C. at 412, 529 S.E.2d at 546; Gurganious v. City of Beaufort, 317 S.C. 481, 488, 454 S.E.2d 912, 916 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding that a party may not argue one ground at trial and an alternate ground on appeal).Â  
Assuming the issue is preserved for our review, we find there was sufficient evidence of damages to submit the case to the jury.Â  In order for damages to be recoverable, the evidence should be sufficient to â€œenable the court or jury to determine the amount thereof with reasonable certainty or accuracy.â€Â  Whisenant v. James Island Corp., 277 S.C. 10, 13, 281 S.E.2d 794, 796 (1981).Â  â€œWhile neither the existence, causation nor amount of damages can be left to conjecture, guess or speculation, proof with mathematical certainty of the amount of loss or damage is not required.â€Â  Id.Â  
Armstrong presented evidence of damages in the form of the loss of his salary and the loss of ten percent of Skillpinsâ€™ profits.Â  Evidence was presented that Armstrong was to receive a guaranteed yearly salary of $150,000, which he lost as a result of the breach.Â  At the time of the agreement, Armstrong expected to work approximately fourteen more years before retiring.Â  However, Armstrong retired shortly after starting his own corporation for health reasons.Â  Thus, Armstrong presented a range of damages from lost salary of $150,000 for one year of work up to $2.1 million over fourteen years.Â  
Armstrong also presented evidence that Collinsâ€™ actions deprived him of the agreed-upon ten percent of the expected profits from Skillpins.Â  Armstrong and Collins planned to have 2,400 Skillpins machines in operation after two years.Â  The machines were eventually placed in the name of Collins Entertainment.Â  Skillpins machines accounted for about two-thirds of the corporationâ€™s revenue after their first full year of operation.Â  The 2001 gross profit from about 400 machines amounted to nearly $2.7 million, with a net profit of approximately $650,000.Â  Ten percent of the 2001 net profit would have amounted to $65,000.Â  Armstrong testified that when all 2,400 machines were in operation, the expected yearly gross profit would have been $16 million, and the net profit, around twenty percent of that, would have been $3.2 million.Â  Armstrong expected to share in ten percent of the net, or $320,000 per year, once the corporation installed all 2,400 machines.Â  Thus, Armstrong presented evidence of lost profits ranging from $65,000 per year up to $320,000 per year.Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Armstrong, evidence was presented regarding damages from Collinsâ€™ actions.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly denied Collinsâ€™ motion for a directed verdict regarding lack of proof of damages.Â  Further, the juryâ€™s verdict of $1.8 million was declared a general verdict by the trial court and was well within the range of damages shown by Armstrong.Â  Because the verdict was a general verdict, we cannot now speculate as to how the jury allocated damages.Â  See Gold Kist , Inc. v. Citizens S. Natâ€™l Bank of S.C., 286 S.C. 272, 282, 333 S.E.2d 67, 73 (Ct. App. 1985) (â€œThe appellate courts of this State exercise every reasonable presumption in favor of the validity of a general verdict.â€).
II. Amendment and Request for Continuance
Collins asserts the trial court erred in allowing Armstrong to amend his complaint to add causes of actions for breach of contract and breach of contract accompanied by fraudulent act and in refusing to grant a continuance or adjournment.Â Â Â  
A.Â  Amendment of the Complaint
Collins argues the trial court erred in allowing Armstrong to conduct the lawsuit based on the alleged fraudulent failure of Collins to create a contract and then amend the complaint on the theory that there was a contract.Â  We disagree. 
Initially, we note that Collins misconstrues Armstrongâ€™s complaint.Â  Rule 8, SCRCP allows inconsistent causes of action; however, we find nothing in the complaint that alleges Collins failed to create a contract.Â  To the contrary, paragraph 3 of the complaint avers â€œPlaintiff and Defendant agreed to the formation of a corporation . . . .â€Â  Paragraph 6 states â€œThe Plaintiff carried out his obligations;â€ and paragraph 8 avers â€œ. . . the Plaintiff had performed under the contract . . .â€ (emphasis added).Â  Thus, contrary to Collinsâ€™ allegation that Armstrong alleged no contract was formed in the complaint, Armstrong clearly alleges that the parties already had a contract.Â  
If a party seeks to amend his pleadings greater than thirty days after a responsive pleading has been filed, he may only do so by leave of the court or with express consent of the other parties.Â  Rule 15(a), SCRCP.Â  Leave to amend the pleadings â€œshall be freely given when justice so requires and does not prejudice any other party.â€Â  Id.Â  Amendments may also be made to conform the pleadings to the evidence when issues not pled are tried by express or implied consent of the parties.Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP.Â  However, implied consent will not be found if all the parties did not recognize it as an issue at trial, even if evidence in the record exists to support the amendment.Â  Dunbar v. Carlson, 341 S.C. 261, 268, 533 S.E.2d 913, 917 (Ct. App. 2000).Â Â Â  
â€œMotions to amend pleadings to conform to proof may be made upon motion of any party at any time, even after judgment . . . .â€Â  Ball v. Canadian Am. Express Co., 314 S.C. 272, 275, 442 S.E.2d 620, 622 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œAmendments to conform to the proof should be liberally allowed when no prejudice to the opposing party will result.â€Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 313, 566 S.E.2d 529, 535 (2002); Kelly v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 316 S.C. 319, 323, 450 S.E.2d 59, 61 (Ct. App. 1994) (holding that amendments are to be freely granted when justice requires and there is no prejudice to any other party).Â  
â€œA motion to amend is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge, and the party opposing the motion has the burden of establishing prejudice.â€Â  Kelly, 316 S.C. at 323, 450 S.E.2d at 61.Â  The prejudice that Rule 15 contemplates is lack of notice that the new issue is to be tried and lack of a full opportunity to introduce testimony to refute it.Â  Soil & Material Engâ€™rs, Inc. v. Folly Assoc., 293 S.C. 498, 501, 361 S.E.2d 779, 781 (Ct. App. 1987).
Although Armstrongâ€™s counsel believed that facts were alleged in the complaint to support the two contract causes of action, he moved, â€œout of an abundance of caution,â€ to amend the pleadings to conform to the proof presented at trial pursuant to Rule 15(b), SCRCP.Â  Despite Collinsâ€™ argument that the contract causes of action were never pled and he was prejudiced by the surprise amendment, the trial court found that the contract causes of action were an integral part of the case.Â  
In determining whether the amendment was proper pursuant to Rule 15(b), SCRCP, we must first address whether the issue of breach of contract was tried by express or implied consent of the parties. Â In Dunbar v. Carlson, 341 S.C. 261, 533 S.E.2d 913 (Ct. App. 2000), this court analyzed implied consent to try a particular issue.Â  In that case, the plaintiff sued the defendant for dental malpractice, and the defendant cross-examined the plaintiffâ€™s daughter regarding the time period during which she warned her mother that the defendant was not giving her adequate care.Â  Based on the daughterâ€™s answers, the defendant moved to amend his pleadings to include the affirmative defense that the statute of limitations had run.Â  Although the plaintiff did not object to the daughterâ€™s testimony and was not aware of the defendantâ€™s intention, the trial court allowed the amendment and immediately granted the defendantâ€™s subsequent motion for a directed verdict.Â  This court reversed, holding that there was no implied consent to try the statute of limitations issue where the daughterâ€™s testimony was admissible for another purpose and she failed to recognize that the defendant intended to assert the statute of limitations.Â  Dunbar, 341 S.C. at 268, 533 SE.2d at 917.Â  
Although Collins cites Dunbar in support of his argument, we believe the facts in this case are distinguishable.Â  In Dunbar, the plaintiff had concluded her case when a new affirmative defense was raised and directed verdict immediately granted.Â  In the case at bar, Armstrongâ€™s unamended complaint alleged â€œThe subject matter of this litigation involves contractual obligations . . . .â€Â  The complaint also alleged that the parties had a contract and that Armstrong performed under the contract.Â  Moreover, in his opening statement, Armstrongâ€™s counsel stated the case concerned whether or not there was a contract between Collins and Armstrong.Â  He informed the jury that it was their job to determine whether there was a meeting of the minds.Â  Although Armstrong testified he had a verbal agreement with Collins, Collinsâ€™ counsel cross-examined Armstrong regarding whether the agreement was actually just a promise to do something in the future.Â  Tim Youmans, an attorney who initially worked for Collins Entertainment and later worked for Armstrong in his new enterprise, testified that Collins informed him that Armstrong would get ten percent of a new corporation that would be a separate entity from Collins Entertainment and the SouthTrust debt.Â  Further, Collins had not begun his defense when the amendment was made.Â  
We find there is sufficient evidence in the record indicating the existence of a contract was an issue at trial.Â  Although Collinsâ€™ counsel noted early in the trial that the issue of breach of contract had not been pled in the case, he questioned Armstrong and Youmans about the particulars of any alleged agreement and whether it was an actual agreement or merely a promise to do something in the future.Â  Armstrong testified extensively that the parties entered into an oral agreement, he trusted Collins would fulfill his end of the bargain, and he would have ten percent of Skillpins, a corporation free and clear of the SouthTrust debt.Â  Thus, despite counselâ€™s assertions at trial that breach of contract was not an issue, both parties elicited testimony regarding a contract and the issue was tried by implied consent.Â  Because whether a contract existed was such an integral part of this case, we do not find that Collins was taken by surprise as was the plaintiff in Dunbar.
We next turn to whether Collins was prejudiced by the amendment.Â  In considering potential prejudice, the court should consider whether the opposing party has had the opportunity to prepare for the issue now being formally raised.Â  Soil & Material Engâ€™rs, Inc. v. Folly Assoc., 293 S.C. 498, 501, 361 S.E.2d 779, 781 (Ct. App. 1987); see also Pool v. Pool, 329 S.C. 324, 328, 494 S.E.2d 820, 823 (1998) (citing Folly Assoc. for the premise that the prejudice contemplated by Rule 15, SCRCP, is the lack of opportunity to refute any new evidence connected with the amended complaint).Â  Armstrong moved for the amendment after presenting all the evidence in support of his case.Â  Collins objected to the amendment, arguing he was prejudiced because he did not have an opportunity to conduct discovery or to cross-examine Armstrong with the contract causes of action in mind.Â  The trial court granted leave to amend, finding that the existence of a contract was an integral part of this case.Â  The court gave Collins the option of recalling Armstrong for further cross-examination on the contract issue, however.Â  Although Collins failed to recall Armstrong for cross-examination, he presented testimony that: the parties never had a â€œmeeting of the minds;â€ there was never an agreement that Skillpins would be free from the SouthTrust debt; and Armstrong was only offered the gift of ten percent of Collins Entertainment.Â Â  
Although Collins argued that he was prejudiced by the amendment because he would have asked different questions on cross-examination and would have presented different evidence, he made no proffer of different questions or evidence, and he was allowed to recall Armstrong if he wanted to do so.Â  We find, based on the facts of this case, that Collins failed to meet his burden of showing prejudice.Â  
Further, we find the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow the amendment was proper pursuant to Rule 15(a), SCRCP.[4]Â  Although Armstrongâ€™s pleadings did not separately delineate causes of action for breach of contract or breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, the facts in the pleadings alleged the following: (1) Armstrong and Collins had a special relationship in which Collins told Armstrong he could trust him; (2) Armstrong developed a business idea, and he and Collins agreed to the formation of a corporation to buy, sell, and distribute coin-operated machines; (3) the agreement between the parties was that Armstrong would receive ten percent of the newly-formed corporation plus a salary of $150,000 per year and that the new corporation would be separate from Collinsâ€™ other business entities and debts; (4) that Armstrong performed under the contract; and (5) notwithstanding the contract between the parties, Collins pledged the new corporation to the bank to secure debts for his other companies and appropriated Armstrongâ€™s idea as his own.Â  These factual allegations were sufficient to support a cause of action for breach of contract and breach of contract accompanied by fraudulent act.Â  Because the allegations were clearly in the pleadings and the issue of the existence of an agreement was addressed at the trial, we find no prejudice to Armstrong in the amendment.Â  Therefore, we find the trial court appropriately allowed the amendment.Â  
In sum, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in allowing the amendment.Â  Armstrongâ€™s complaint did not allege that Collins failed to create a contract, as Collins asserts.Â  Clearly, the existence of a contract was an issue at trial, and Collins was not prejudiced by the amendment.Â  Finally, Armstrongâ€™s complaint alleges facts that would support the causes of action for breach of contract and breach of contract accompanied by fraudulent act.
B. Continuance
Collins next asserts that even if the trial court properly granted leave to amend, it erred in refusing to continue or adjourn the case to give defense counsel time to prepare.Â  We disagree.Â  
The decision whether to grant leave to amend is within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Soil & Material Engâ€™rs, Inc. v. Folly Assoc., 293 S.C. 498, 501, 361 S.E.2d 779, 781 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  However, when a late amendment would cause prejudice to the opposing party, the trial court should either deny the amendment or grant a continuance to allow the time reasonably necessary to prepare for the new issue.Â  Ball, 314 S.C. at 275, 442 S.E.2d at 622.Â  Nevertheless, the decision to grant or deny a continuance is a matter within the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Graybar Elec. Co. v. Rice, 287 S.C. 518, 520, 339 S.E.2d 883, 884 (Ct. App. 1986).Â Â  
After the trial court denied Collinsâ€™ motion for a directed verdict, he moved for a continuance or an adjournment of the trial, to â€œrestart it sometime in the future,â€ because he was taken by surprise that the contract causes of action would be a part of the trial.Â  The trial court found the contract issue so completely integral and intertwined with the other issues in the case that a continuance or adjournment was unnecessary in light of the need for judicial economy.Â  However, the court granted Collins the right to recall Armstrong as a witness at any point in the trial.Â  Collins never recalled Armstrong for further cross-examination.Â  
Moreover, Collins had notice of an alleged contract and its breach from the moment he was served with the complaint.Â  He had ample time to conduct discovery and formulate questions on the issue.Â  Considering the theory of his defense â€“ that he only made a promise of a future gift â€“ it is highly unlikely that Collins did not contemplate the contract issue.Â  
As discussed above, Collins presented evidence in his case that there was no agreement.Â  Thus, he failed to show any actual prejudice from the courtâ€™s decision to allow the amendment.Â  Based on these facts, we find no abuse of discretion in the courtâ€™s decision to deny the motion for a continuance at such a late date in the trial. 
CONCLUSION
We hold that the trial court correctly denied Collinsâ€™ motion for directed verdict on all six remaining causes of action.Â  We further hold that the damages issue was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Finally, we find no abuse of discretion in allowing the amendment to the pleadings to include the contract causes of action and in denying the request for a continuance or adjournment.Â  Accordingly, the judgment in favor of Armstrong is hereby 
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J. and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Collins was not personally liable on this debt.Â  
[2] The goal was to have 2,400 machines in operation after the first two years.Â Â  
[3]Â  Collins also mentions in his brief that there was â€œno evidence of any accompanying fraud.â€Â  However, he fails to present any argument or caselaw in support of this assertion.Â  Thus, this argument is abandoned on appeal and we decline to address it.Â  See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (noting that where a party fails to cite any supporting authority or where the argument is merely a conclusory statement, the issue is deemed abandoned on appeal).
[4]Â  This court may affirm the trial court based on any grounds found in the record.Â  Rule 220(c), SCACR; Iâ€™on, LLC v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 418, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000).Â

title: Corbin v. Carlin
description: In this action to quiet title, Carlin appeals, arguing  the trial court erred in finding the landowner could challenge the tax sale of the property because the statute of limitations had run.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Russell B. Corbin, Respondent,
v.
Bernard Thomas Carlin, Jr., and James E. Peterson,
Defendants,
Of Whom Bernard Thomas Carlin, Jr. is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4029
Heard June 17, 2005 â€“ Filed October 3, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mark H. Lund, III, of Bluffton, for Appellant.
John J. Kerr, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â Â Â Â Â Â  This case involves a dispute to title of property.Â  Bernard Thomas Carlin, Jr. appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding Russell B. Corbin held title to the property and voiding the tax sale of the property to Carlinâ€™s predecessor.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The property at issue is a long, narrow strip of land referred to by the parties as Tract B and is located on Yonges Island in Charleston County.Â  Tract B was 1.07 acres, was originally subdivided from a larger piece of property, and was deeded to Thompson Farms.Â  In March 1984, Thompson Farms conveyed Tract B to Henry Lowndes.Â  
In December 1985, Thompson Farms conveyed a 5.99-acre tract of land (â€œTract 1â€) to Russell Corbin.Â  The description of Tract 1 in the deed from Thompson Farms to Corbin described the parcel as including the 1.07 acres of Tract B.Â  At the time of this conveyance, Thompson Farms did not own Tract B.Â  However, two weeks later, in January 1986, Lowndes conveyed Tract B back to Thompson Farms.Â  These exchanges were part of a three-way exchange and sale involving Corbin, Thompson Farms, and Lowndes.Â  In the final part of this exchange, Thompson Farms deeded property known as Tract C to Lowndes that was bounded on the east by Tract B.Â  The description in the deed stated that it was bounded on the east by lands â€œrecently conveyed to Russell Corbin.â€Â Â  
The county listed Thompson Farms as the owner of Tract B, even though pursuant to the prior sale, Corbin owned Tract 1 that included Tract B in its 5.99 acres.Â  Corbin paid taxes on the entirety of Tract 1, which included Tract B.Â  Tract B was used by Corbin as an airstrip, and he leased use of the airstrip to Bernard Carlin from 1990 to 1995.Â  However, in 1990, the county mailed tax notices to Thompson Farms for Tract B.Â  Thompson Farms ignored these notices.Â  On July 6, 1992, Charleston County sold Tract B in a tax sale to James E. Peterson for $400.Â  He received the tax deed in August 1993.Â  Peterson later conveyed the property to Carlin in October 1997. 
Corbin eventually discovered that Tract B had been sold and then conveyed to Carlin.Â  In August 2001, he brought a declaratory judgment action against Carlin and Carlinâ€™s predecessor in title, Peterson.Â  The action sought to quiet title to Tract B and to have the tax sale, deed, and any mortgage on the property declared null and void.[1]Â  Carlin answered, denying the allegations in the complaint and asserting the two-year time limit found in section 12-51-160 of the South Carolina Code barred the action. 
At trial, Corbin offered the testimony of Curtis Lybrand as a professional land surveyor.Â  He testified regarding the various transactions and the descriptions of the property.Â  He also testified if one researched the three-way deals, it would have placed the individual on notice that Corbin owned Tract B because at least one other deed description referred to the bordering land, Tract B, as belonging to Corbin.Â  He also testified Tract B as described in the tax deed to Peterson did not exist.Â  Finally, he testified the only property which was described as Tract B that he could locate was within Tract 1 and owned by Corbin at the time of the tax sale.Â  
Carlin testified he did no research into what property he purchased from Peterson.Â  He testified in 1999 he purchased property from Lowndes to the west of Tract 1.Â  At the time of the survey, he also assumed Tract B was to the west of Tract 1 and not within its boundaries.Â  When the survey was complete he admitted to being shocked that the tax deed was for property within the land encompassed by Tract 1 and owned by Corbin.Â  
At the end of Corbinâ€™s case, Carlinâ€™s counsel stated:Â  â€œIâ€™d like to make a motion to dismiss.â€Â  The parties then discussed the ramifications of section 12-51-160 and whether the instant action was one to set aside a tax sale so as to fall within the sectionâ€™s purview.Â  The trial court denied the motion.Â  
Carlin then called Peterson to the stand to offer testimony.Â  At the end of his case, Carlin again moved to dismiss the case, simply stating:Â  â€œAnd weâ€™ll rest the defense. . . . And renew our motion to dismiss.â€Â  The court made no explicit ruling on the motion, but it directed Corbinâ€™s counsel to draft a proposed order ruling in Corbinâ€™s favor.Â  
In the final order, the court found Corbin owned Tract B through the doctrine of after-acquired property.Â  The court then concluded the tax notices were in error and the tax sale and deed were null and void.Â  Finally, the court found Corbin the proper owner of Tract B.Â  The order failed to rule on the application of section 12-51-160 to the action.Â  
Carlin filed a motion for reconsideration under Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  The motion stated in part:Â  â€œGrounds therefore will be that the findings, conclusions, holdings, and judgment contained in the referenced Order [the courtâ€™s final order] are contrary to the record, without evidentiary support, and contrary to the statutory and case law of South Carolina, in such cases made and provided.â€Â  The motion never specifically asked the court to consider section 12-51-160 as barring the action.Â  The court denied the motion for reconsideration, again without mentioning section 12-51-160.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This is an appeal from a decision in a declaratory judgment action.Â  Declaratory judgments are neither legal nor equitable, but the nature of the action is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991); Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co., 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œAn action to remove a cloud on and quiet title to land is one in equity.â€Â  Bryan v. Freeman, 253 S.C. 50, 52, 168 S.E.2d 793, 793 (1969).Â  In actions at equity, tried before a judge alone, we are free to find the facts according to our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Townes Assocs. Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  However, the decision to grant a declaratory judgment is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Eargle v. Horry County, 344 S.C. 449, 453, 545 S.E.2d 276, 279 (2001). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Carlin contends the trial court erred in failing to find the action was barred under application of the time limit found in section 12-51-160 of the South Carolina Code.[2]Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note that the trial court found Corbin acquired title through the application of the doctrine of after-acquired property.Â  See Richardson v. Atlantic Coast Lumber Corp., 93 S.C. 254, 258, 75 S.E. 371, 372 (1912) (â€œThe principle is settled beyond controversy in this state that if a grantor conveys land, with the usual covenants of warranty, to which at that time he has no title, but afterwards acquires a title, he is estopped from claiming that he did not have title at the time of the sale; and the after-acquired title inures to the benefit of his grantee.â€).Â  The trial courtâ€™s determination that Corbin acquired Tract B through the doctrine of after-acquired property has not been appealed, and it is therefore the law of the case.Â  See Unisun Ins. v. Hawkins, 342 S.C. 537, 544, 537 S.E.2d 559, 563 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting an unappealed ruling is the law of the case which the appellate court must assume was correct).Â  Thus, we must determine the application of the statute to the situation where Corbin had good title to Tract B.Â  
Section 12-51-160 provides that the tax sale deed is evidence of good title and that â€œall proceedings have been regular and that all legal requirements have been complied with.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-160 (2000).Â  The section further provides a time limit for recovering land sold pursuant to a tax sale:Â  â€œNo action for the recovery of land sold under the provisions of this chapter or for the recovery of the possession may be maintained unless brought within two years from the date of sale.â€Â  Id.Â  
To determine the application of this section on the present case, we must apply the rules of statutory construction.Â  â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€Â  Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 39, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207 (2003); Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 122, 542 S.E.2d 736, 739 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAll rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one that the legislative intent must prevail if it reasonably can be discovered in the language used, and the language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.â€Â  City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda Truck (VIN # JM2UF1132N0294812), 330 S.C. 371, 375, 498 S.E.2d 894, 896 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œStatutes, as a whole, must receive practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation, consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of lawmakers.â€ Â TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 624, 503 S.E.2d 471, 478 (1998).Â Â  
If a statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning â€œthe rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose another meaning.â€Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  The words of the statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  â€œOur goal in construing statutes is to prevent an interpretation that would lead to a result that is plainly absurd.â€Â  In re Timothy C.M., 348 S.C. 653, 655-56, 560 S.E.2d 452, 453 (Ct. App. 2002).
We find section 12-51-160 was not intended to bar an action under the circumstances of this case.Â  The legislature intended the statute to create a time limit during which one who lost title to property through a tax sale, after proper notice, may attempt to regain title.Â  In this case, Corbin never lost title to the property, as the tax sale should never have occurred.Â  We agree with the trial courtâ€™s finding that Corbin properly paid taxes owed on Tract 1, which included Tract B.[3]Â  There is nothing in the record to indicate he was on notice that Thompson Farms received tax notices for Tract B or that Thompson Farms ignored those notices.Â  Because the taxes for Tract 1, including Tract B, were not delinquent, the county did not have any basis for conducting the tax sale on Tract B.Â Â  
We find the instant action was not one to set aside a tax sale falling under the provision of section 12-51-160, but instead was an action to quiet title and for Corbin to assert his proper ownership rights to Tract B.Â  It would yield an absurd and unfair result to forbid Corbin to assert his right to ownership of his property when there is no indication he knew or should have known the county was improperly seeking to sell the property in a tax sale.Â  The court properly found Corbin had title to Tract B.Â  It also properly found the county erred in conducting a tax sale.Â  The evidence indicates Corbin paid taxes assessed against Tract 1, which unquestionably included Tract B.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly refused to find, based upon the circumstances of this case, that the statute of limitations found in section 12-51-160 barred the action.
Considering the particular circumstances of this case, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s decision to grant Corbinâ€™s declaratory judgment.
CONCLUSION
Based upon the above, we hold section 12-51-160 did not bar the instant action to quiet title.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Corbin also brought an action seeking damages for slander of title, alleging Carlinâ€™s deed placed a cloud on his title.Â  The trial court denied Corbinâ€™s request for damages, finding no slander of title.Â  
[2]Â  Carlin states the statute controlling the time during which challenges to tax sales may be made is a statute of repose.Â  The statute itself, however, is entitled â€œDeed as evidence of good title; statute of limitations.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-160 (2000).Â  The section appears to operate as a statute of repose, which creates â€œâ€˜a substantive right in those protected to be free from liability after a legislatively-determined period of time.â€™â€Â  Langley v. Pierce, 313 S.C. 401, 403-04, 438 S.E.2d 242, 243 (1993) (quoting First United Methodist Church v. U.S. Gypsum Co., 882 F.2d 862, 866 (4th Cir. 1989)).Â  Whether the statute is one of limitations or one of repose, however, is not a question we must address in order to decide the issues on appeal.Â  Therefore, we decline to analyze it.Â  Because the statute is entitled â€œstatute of limitations,â€ we will refer to the statute as one of limitations for the sake of clarity.Â  
[3] Carlin also alleges that the trial court erred in finding no taxes were delinquent on Tract B.Â  As previously discussed, it is the law of the case that Corbin obtained title to Tract B, as a part of Tract 1, through the doctrine of after-acquired property.Â  Carlin does not challenge evidence that Corbin paid the taxes owed on Tract 1.Â  Because Corbin was not delinquent on taxes owed on property that included Tract B, we find no error with the trial courtâ€™s determination that no taxes were delinquent on Tract B.
