title: State v. Wharton
description: Wharton appeals from his conviction for voluntary manslaughter, arguing the trial judge erred in: (1) charging voluntary manslaughter; (2) failing to charge involuntary manslaughter; and (3) failing to charge accident.  We reverse.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Danny Orlando Wharton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4014
Heard January 13, 2005 â€“ Filed July 5, 2005
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled October 10, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, of Columbia; Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Danny Orlando Wharton was convicted of voluntary manslaughter and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial judge erred in: (1) charging the law of voluntary manslaughter; (2) failing to charge the jury on the law of involuntary manslaughter; and (3) failing to charge the jury on the law of accident.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Danny Orlando Wharton and several of his friends were at a neighborâ€™s house playing cards when his ex-girlfriend, Pam Suber, confronted him about his new girlfriend.Â  The two began arguing, and several people gathered around to break up the argument.Â  Suber left the area after the argument, while five or six people, including Whartonâ€™s best friend, Chris Luster, and Clifton â€œSmokeyâ€ Shaw, attempted to calm Wharton down. Â Wharton resisted the attempts to calm him down and did not want to be touched.Â  At some point, he exchanged words with Shaw about Suber.Â  Wharton retrieved a gun from a vehicle parked nearby.Â  Shaw told his girlfriend to take his son home out of the way.Â  He then approached Wharton in an aggressive manner.Â  The two continued to argue.Â  Shaw placed his necklace beneath his shirt collar to prepare for a physical altercation and Wharton pulled the gun out.Â  According to Shaw, who was the object of the argument, Wharton pulled the gun out like he was trying to shoot it into the air.Â  Shaw testified that he turned and lay down, the gun discharged, and Luster, who was attempting to end the argument between Wharton and Shaw, was fatally shot.Â  A witness testified that Wharton was shocked that Luster was shot.Â  
Wharton was indicted for murder and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  The State requested a jury charge on murder and voluntary manslaughter.Â  Wharton opposed the voluntary manslaughter charge.Â  He argued alternatively that if the judge gave the voluntary manslaughter charge, he was entitled to a charge on involuntary manslaughter and accident.Â  The judge denied the requests, and the jury was charged on the law of murder, voluntary manslaughter, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.[1] Â The jury found Wharton guilty of voluntary manslaughter and possession of a weapon during the commission or attempt to commit a violent crime.Â  The judge sentenced him to prison for a total of fifteen years.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.â€Â  State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 302, 555 S.E.2d 391, 394 (2001).Â  â€œOnly the law applicable to the case should be charged to the jury.â€Â  State v. Blurton, 352 S.C. 203, 208, 573 S.E.2d 802, 804 (2002).Â  â€œIf a jury instruction is provided to the jury that does not fit the facts of the case, it may confuse the jury.â€Â  Id.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wharton argues the trial judge erred in charging the jury on voluntary manslaughter.Â  We agree.Â  
Voluntary manslaughter is the â€œunlawful killing of a human being in the sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation.â€Â  Knoten, 347 S.C. at 302, 555 S.E.2d at 394.Â  Both heat of passion and sufficient legal provocation must be present for the killing to constitute voluntary manslaughter.Â  Id.; State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 101-02, 525 S.E.2d 511, 513 (2000).Â  Sufficient legal provocation must come from the victim, not from a third party.Â  Harris, 354 S.C. at 387, 581 S.E.2d at 156.Â  To constitute sufficient legal provocation to support a voluntary manslaughter charge, the provocation â€œmust come from some act of or related to the victim.â€Â  State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 363, 535 S.E.2d 420, 425 (2000).Â  
We find no evidence of sufficient legal provocation that would support a charge of voluntary manslaughter.Â  The pertinent facts are undisputed as to the lack of provocation by the victim, Chris Luster.Â  Although Wharton was arguing with Shaw at the time of the shooting, the evidence elicited at trial showed there was never any argument or discord between Wharton and Luster.Â  
The State argues, however, that the principle of transferred intent is applicable.Â  This argument is unavailing.Â  As previously discussed, sufficient provocation necessary to justify a voluntary manslaughter charge must come from the victim and not transferred from a third party.Â  Harris, 354 S.C. at 387, 581 S.E.2d at 156; Locklair, 341 S.C. at 363, 535 S.E.2d at 425.Â  Further, â€œ[w]here death is caused by the use of a deadly weapon, words alone, however opprobrious, are not sufficient to constitute a legal provocation.â€Â  State v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 322, 474 S.E.2d 430, 432 (1996); State v. Cooley, 342 S.C. 63, 68, 536 S.E.2d 666, 669 (2000).Â  Here, Wharton and Shaw were only arguing.Â  Thus, there was no legal provocation to transfer.Â  Moreover, transferred intent does not supplant the necessary element of legal provocation required for voluntary manslaughter.Â  
Because there is no evidence of sufficient legal provocation, the trial judge should not have given a voluntary manslaughter instruction.Â  Wharton was clearly prejudiced because he was found guilty of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Accordingly, we reverse Whartonâ€™s conviction for voluntary manslaughter.Â  
Further, Whartonâ€™s conviction for voluntary manslaughter was a prerequisite to his conviction for possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490(E) (2003) (noting that the additional punishment for possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime may not be imposed unless the defendant is convicted of the underlying violent crime); State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 235 n.4, 589 S.E.2d 1, 5 n.4 (2003) (noting that defendantâ€™s conviction for possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime must be reversed where the court was reversing defendantâ€™s murder conviction).Â  Thus, because we reverse the voluntary manslaughter conviction, we necessarily must reverse the conviction for the weapon charge.
Having reversed the trial court on the voluntary manslaughter charge, we need not address appellantâ€™s remaining issues.Â  
CONCLUSION
Because the trial judge erred in charging the law of voluntary manslaughter, Whartonâ€™s convictions and sentences are
REVERSED.
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  In fact, the jury was charged twice with the law of voluntary manslaughter because the jury requested the definition of manslaughter and asked whether involuntary manslaughter was an option.Â  The jury was also charged three times with the law of transferred intent after the jury requested a clarification and a question arose regarding whether or not transferred intent could be used for voluntary manslaughter.Â  See Harris v. State, 354 S.C. 382, 387, 581 S.E.2d 154, 156 (2003) (â€œSufficient provocation necessary to justify a voluntary manslaughter charge must come from the victim and not be transferred from a third party to the victim.â€).

title: Blackmon v. Weaver
description: In this will construction case, the majority determined that the testator's intention was to devise to his widow a life estate coupled with a power to dispose, and the full panel concluded it was error to remove the widow as personal representative.
text:
Blackmon v. Weaver

<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Lana Odom Blackmon, Individually and as Personal Representative of the Will and Estate of J. B. Blackmon, Jr., Deceased,
Appellant,
v.
Jennifer B. Weaver, Edmund Cole Weaver as Trustee for Nicholas Weaver, Mary Heath and J. B. Blackmon, III,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4030
Heard October 13, 2004 â€“ Filed October 17, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
B. Michael Brackett, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Adele Jeffords Pope, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Lana Blackmon, the personal representative and a beneficiary under her late husbandâ€™s will, requested the probate court to construe the will.Â  After removal to the circuit court, the judge construed the will to grant Lana an estate less than one for life and removed her as personal representative.Â  Lana appeals, and we reverse. Â 
FACTS
J.B. Blackmon and Lana Odom were married in February 2000 after a courtship lasting approximately six years.Â  It was J.B.â€™s fourth marriage and Lanaâ€™s third.Â  Prior to the marriage, J.B. had been diagnosed with terminal cancer and in February of 2001, he died.Â  J.B.â€™s will named Lana personal representative and devised to her an interest in the estate.Â  The will also devised interests to J.B.â€™s three children from his first marriage, Jennifer Weaver, Mary Heath, and J.B. Blackmon, III.Â  The nature of the partiesâ€™ interests in the estate property is at the heart of this action.Â  J.B.â€™s will reads in pertinent part:

Second:Â  I give, devise and bequeath all of my property whether real, personal or mixed, whatsoever and wheresoever situate, whether now owned by me or to me or hereafter acquired by me, to my wife, Lana Odom Blackmon for and during her natural life or until such time as she no longer desires the property.
Sixth:Â  That if the desire of my wife to sell any or all of my property and assets then my wife,
Mary B. Heath, J.B. Blackmon, III and Jennifer B. Weaver, shall share equally in the sale of such assets or proceeds from the sale of such assets. 

Lana argues she has a life estate in all of J.B.â€™s property pursuant to these provisions.Â  The children take the position that J.B.â€™s devise does not permit Lana to dispose of some of the assets, specifically the family farm and certain stocks.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to construe a will is an action at law.Â  NationsBank of S.C. v. Greenwood, 321 S.C. 386, 392, 468 S.E.2d 658, 662 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  An action to remove a personal representative is equitable in nature.Â  Dean v. Kilgore, 313 S.C. 257, 259, 437 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  When legal and equitable causes of action are maintained in one suit, the court is presented with a divided scope of review.Â  Perry v. Heirs at Law and Distributees of Gadsden, 313 S.C. 296, 300 n.3, 437 S.E.2d 174, 177 n.3 (Ct. App. 1993) (affâ€™d as modified, 316 S.C. 224, 449 S.E.2d 250 (1994)).Â  On appeal from an action at law that was tried without a jury, the appellate court can correct errors of law, but the findings of fact will not be disturbed unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assoc. Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  In an equitable action tried without a jury, the appellate court can correct errors of law and may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Id. at 86, 221 S.E.2d at 775-76.
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Will Construction
Lana argues the trial court erred in construing the will to grant her a limited right of use and enjoyment in the family farm and related personal property.Â  We agree.
Lana requests that this court construe her interest as a life estate with the power of disposition.Â  Our courts have previously recognized such an interest.Â  See Johnson v. Waldrop, 256 S.C. 372, 374-76, 182 S.E.2d 730, 731 (1971) (finding a life estate with a complete power to dispose and consume); Thomason v. Hellams, 233 S.C. 11, 15, 103 S.E.2d 324, 325 (1958) (holding that â€œ[a] deed, devise or bequest for life with power of disposition and remainder to another (of such property as is not disposed of by the first taker) is valid.â€).Â  In this case, the trial court took a clear provision of the will creating a life estate and then reduced it by construing the language of a subsequent provision.Â  We refuse to do so.Â  
Item two reads as follows:Â  â€œI give, devise and bequeath all of my property . . . to my wife . . . for and during her natural life.â€Â  These words clearly indicate J.B.â€™s intent to give a life estate in all of his property to Lana.Â  Where the wording of a will is clear and unambiguous, the testatorâ€™s intention must be ascertained from the language utilized.Â  Shelley v. Shelley, 244 S.C. 598, 602, 137 S.E.2d 851, 853 (1964).Â  There is no special language required for the creation of a life estate; courts will look to the intention of the creator of the estate.Â  See 28 Am. Jur. 2d Estates Â§ 67 (2005).Â  The trial court, relying on the limiting language â€œor until such time as she no longer desires the property,â€ determined that J.B. granted Lana only the limited right of use and enjoyment to the property.Â  However, we do not believe this was a correct application of the law.Â  â€œ[W]here an estate or interest is given in words of clear and ascertained legal signification, it shall not be enlarged, cut down, or destroyed by superadded words in the same or subsequent clauses, unless they raise an irresistible inference that such was the intention.â€Â  McGirt v. Nelson, 360 S.C. 307, 311, 599 S.E.2d 620, 622 (Ct. App. 2004) (internal citations omitted).Â  
J.B.â€™s intent is further evidenced by an examination of item six.Â  Item six unequivocally grants Lana the authority to dispose of the entirety of the estateâ€™s assets subject to J.B.â€™s children receiving a portion of the proceeds of any sale.Â  To hold, in the face of this language, that Lana was not given the right to dispose of the property would require us to completely ignore this provision as it is written.Â  To do so would be error.Â  See Hays v. Adair, 267 S.C. 291, 296, 227 S.E.2d 665, 667-68 (1976) (stating that â€œ[a] proper construction seeks to harmonize the various provisions and a construction which gives meaning to all should be preferred over one which renders some provisions meaningless.â€); see also May v. Riley, 279 S.C. 248, 250-51, 305 S.E.2d 77, 78 (1983) (considering two provisions and concluding that neither can be ignored).Â Â  
A court may not â€œby judicial construction make a will for the decedent that he has not made for himself.â€Â  Guaranty Bank & Trust Co. v. Byrd, 287 S.C. 96, 99, 337 S.E.2d 231, 233 (Ct. App. 1985) (quoting Coffman v. Coffman, 85 Va. 459, 466, 8 S.E. 672, 675 (1888)), revâ€™d on other grounds, 292 S.C. 187, 355 S.E.2d 529 (1986).Â  Because the language of J.B.â€™s will clearly shows his intent to grant his wife a life estate with the power of disposition, we reverse the ruling of the trial court.Â  
II.Â  Removal of Personal Representative
Lana also argues the trial court erred in removing her as personal representative.Â  We agree.
Section 62-3-611(b) of the South Carolina Code (1976) governs removal of a personal representative, and allows for removal when it is in the best interest of the estate, when the personal representative mismanages the estate, or when the personal representative fails to perform any duty pertaining to the office.Â  However, there is a strong deference shown to the personal representative chosen by the testator.Â  â€œThe Courts have ever been reluctant to take the management of an estate from those to whom it has been confided by the testator, for to that extent the intention expressed in his will would be defeated.â€Â  Smith v. Heyward, 115 S.C. 145, 164, 105 S.E. 275, 282 (1920).Â  The power to remove a personal representative â€œshould be executed with great caution, and not at all, unless it is made to appear to be necessary for the protection of the estate, to prevent loss or injury to it from misappropriation, maladministration or fraud.â€Â  Id. at 164-65, 105 S.E. at 282. 
The trial court removed Lana as personal representative because she requested the court to construe the will and took a position that strongly favored her own interests.Â  The court also cited Lanaâ€™s failure to timely act to collect a $70,000 debt owed to the estate and her hostility toward other beneficiaries.Â  The trial court found this hostility was displayed by failing to allow access to the family house and farm.Â  
A review of the record shows Lana had, in fact, disclosed the existence of the debt on the estate inventory.Â  In addition, Lana was in the process of obtaining a default judgment against the debtor, which would allow her to proceed with collection efforts on behalf of the estate.Â  As for any failure to timely obtain the judgment, Lana testified she talked to approximately six attorneys regarding the debt and found it difficult to obtain anyone to represent the estate in the action.Â  Therefore, it appears that Lana has neither mismanaged the estate nor failed to perform a required duty.
Regarding hostility between Lana and other beneficiaries, Lana admits she ceased talking to Jennifer Weaver because of conflict between the two.Â  However, it is uncontested that on one occasion Lana allowed the children to walk through the house and take some items.Â  Later, Lana delivered other items to one of the daughters.Â  The mere existence of conflict between a personal representative and a beneficiary is an inadequate reason for removal of the personal representative.Â  Without a showing of fault, the court will not remove a personal representative simply because the parties do not get along.Â 
Reed v. South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank, 293 S.C. 357, 360 S.E.2d 527 (Ct. App. 1987) (discussing a trustee rather than a personal representative).Â  Therefore, we find the trial court erred in ordering the removal of Lana as personal representative.
CONCLUSION
Because the plain language of the will grants a life estate with the right of disposition, and because the request to remove the personal representative was without merit, the decision of the trial court is
REVERSED.
BEATTY, J., concurs.
SHORT, J., dissents in part in a separate opinion.
J. Short, dissenting in part:  Although I agree with the majority that the trial court erred in removing Lana as personal representative, I disagree with the majority’s determination of Lana’s interest and find that J.B. intended for her to have a life estate in all of his property.  Furthermore, I believe he intended for her to have the power to sell any property not otherwise described specifically in paragraphs three and five of the will; however, should she sell any of the remaining assets she should share the proceeds as provided for in the will.  Although the will is inadequately drawn, my construction would attempt to harmonize its provisions and give somewhat equivalent effect to each provision so as to effectuate J.B.’s intent.  
Lana requests this court to construe her interest as a life estate because our courts have previously recognized a grantee may have a life estate coupled with the power to dispose.  See Johnson v. Waldrop, 256 S.C. 372, 375, 182 S.E.2d 730, 731 (1971) (finding a life estate with a complete power to dispose and consume); Thomason v. Hellams, 233 S.C. 11, 15, 103 S.E.2d 324, 325 (1958).  In Johnson and Thomason, separate provisions in each will clearly created the life estates with the power to dispose while in the instant case, this court would have to take an ordinarily clear and separate provision of the will and limit it by a subsequent provision to construe such an interest.  “In determining the testator’s intent, the [c]ourt should read the will as a whole and attempt to harmonize all its provisions.”  May v. Riley, 279 S.C. 248, 250, 305 S.E.2d 77, 78 (1983).  “An interpretation that fits into the whole scheme or plan of the will is the most apt to be the correct interpretation of the intent of the testator.”  Kemp v. Rawlings, 358 S.C. 28, 34, 594 S.E.2d 845, 849 (2004).  
The court’s primary purpose when construing a will is to consider the will as a whole and arrive at the testator’s intention.  Shelley v. Shelley, 244 S.C. 598, 601, 137 S.E.2d 851, 853 (1964).  This court must determine from paragraphs two, three, five, and six of J.B.’s will what type of estate J.B. granted to Lana.[1]  The lower court determined the will’s language limited Lana’s interest to “her natural life or until such time as she no longer desires the property.”  Although the court granted Lana a limited right of use and enjoyment, a plain reading of paragraph two clearly indicates J.B. intended to give Lana a life estate in all of his property.  There is no special language required for the creation of a life estate and courts look to the intention of the creator of the estate.  See 28 Am. Jur. 2d Estates § 67 (2000).  The “for and during her natural life” language attests to J.B.’s intent to create a life estate in favor of his wife.  
Paragraph three, which begins with the word “[t]hen,” indicates J.B.’s desire for his daughter Jennifer to follow Lana’s interest in the family farm after Lana dies or no longer desires the property.  A plain reading of paragraph three presents the probability that J.B. contemplated that he was arranging for Lana to remain on the property, which in fact was the marital home, until she no longer desired to live there.  Should that time come before her death, it is reasonable to assume that he provided that it should then pass to his daughter, rather than Jennifer having to wait until Lana’s death.  More explicitly, paragraph three grants Nicolas Weaver, Jennifer’s son, the property if Jennifer “is deceased at the time of the death of my wife or at the time my wife desires to no longer use the property . . . .”  This statement signifies the unmistakable intent on the part of J.B. for the farm to remain in the family by contemplating no scenario for the transfer of the farm beyond the death or voluntary surrender by Lana by deeming it to pass to not one, but to a second generational heir, should the first bequest fail.  
Paragraph five grants Mary Heath and J.B. Blackmon, III, J.B.’s other children, an interest in the PLM partnerships and uses identical language as paragraph three as to when they take the property.  The “no longer desires the property” language in paragraphs three and five underscores J.B.’s desire for his children to receive his interest in the partnerships at the time of Lana’s death or when she no longer desired the property. 
Paragraph six creates the problematic portion of the will by providing for proceeds distribution should Lana desire “to sell any or all of my property and assets.” (emphasis added).  Read alone, paragraph six grants Lana the authority to dispose of the entirety of the estate’s assets unconditionally, subject to J.B.’s children receiving a portion of the proceeds of any sale.  If allowed such weight and analyzed with the entire will, paragraph six seems to limit taking of the interests in paragraphs three and five by the cited beneficiaries to two scenarios: Lana dying before selling the property or Lana voluntarily relinquishing her rights to the property during her lifetime.  A fundamental rule of construction of wills is that the court makes every effort to give effect to every provision of the will and endeavors to reconcile two apparently inconsistent provisions rather than to give effect to one over the other.  Shelley, 244 S.C. at 601-03, 137 S.E.2d. at 853.  Under this analysis, Lana’s decision to sell the farm would reduce Jennifer’s potential interest in the farm from fee simple to a mere shared portion of the proceeds.  The clear intent of paragraph three belies this result, and I do not believe J.B. intended paragraph six to supersede the other paragraphs of the will.
The lower court heard testimony that the farmhouse was built in 1822 and had been bought by J.B.’s grandfather in 1937.  J.B. grew up on the farm, known as “White Plains” from the time he was ten years old and after he returned to live there, he worked to place the house on the National Register of Historic Places.  The record is clear and both sides agree that J.B. had a great deal of fondness for the property; therefore, I find that he did not intend to give Lana the power to dispose of White Plains.  I find J.B. included paragraph six in the will to permit Lana to sell various assets for her support as needed, but I believe J.B. did not contemplate the sale of either the PLM partnerships or White Plains to satisfy this commitment.

[1] In addition to the second and sixth paragraphs of the will referred to in the majority opinion, J.B.’s will provides, in pertinent part:
Third:  Then I give, devise and bequeath to my daughter, Jennifer B. Weaver, my farm and home and all personal property held for the benefit of such real property.  If Jennifer B. Weaver, is deceased at the time of the death of my wife or at the time my wife desires to no longer use the property, then to Edwin Cole Weaver as Trustee for my grandson, Nicolas Weaver to be held until he reaches the age of eighteen (18) and then conveyed to him as Tenants in Common.  
. . . .
Fifth:  Also at the time of the death of my wife or at such time as she no longer desires the property, I give and bequeath to my children, Mary B. Heath, and J.B. Blackmon, III, all of my interest in PLM V and VI including any earnings or cash attached to such interest along with such principal which may arise at maturity.  If either of my children predecease my wife at the time of her death or when she no longer desires this property then the remainder shall be divided between the surviving child and Jennifer B. Weaver.

title: Browning v. Browning
description: In this domestic contempt action, Husband appeals the family court's order, arguing the court erred in:  (1) finding Husband in contempt for failing to timely comply with the parties' Property Settlement Agreement; (2) ordering Husband to submit to a medical examination so that Wife could obtain a life insurance policy on Husband; (3) addressing issues regarding a life insurance policy for the benefit of the parties' emancipated son; and (4) awarding Wife attorney's fees.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Rhonda W. Browning, Respondent,
v.
Gregory W. Browning, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â A. E. â€œGeneâ€ Morehead, III, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4031
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed October 17, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND MODIFIED IN PART


  
    
      
Spencer Andrew Syrett, of Columbia, for Appellant.
James M. Saleeby, Sr., of Florence and Marian D. Nettles, of Lake City; for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  In this domestic contempt action, Gregory W. Browning (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s order, arguing the court erred in:Â  (1) finding Husband in contempt for failing to timely comply with the partiesâ€™ Property Settlement Agreement; (2) ordering Husband to submit to a medical examination so that Rhonda W. Browning (Wife) could obtain a life insurance policy on Husband; (3) addressing issues regarding a life insurance policy for the benefit of the partiesâ€™ emancipated son; and (4) awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and modify in part.[1]  
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married on August 16, 1975, and had one child during the marriage. Â On September 15, 2000, the parties separated.Â  Prior to a hearing for temporary relief, the parties entered into a Property Settlement Agreement (Agreement) on March 7, 2001.Â  By order dated May 29, 2001, the family court approved the Agreement.Â  The parties were later divorced on July 8, 2002. 
On February 2, 2004, Wife filed an action seeking to hold Husband in contempt for violating the Agreement.Â  In her amended complaint, Wife alleged, inter alia, Husband:Â  (1) failed to pay Wife her one-half share of the equity in the former marital home within thirty days of Wife vacating the home; (2) refused to submit to a medical examination in order that Wife could obtain a life insurance policy on Husband; and (3) failed to provide proof of coverage to Wife regarding a $2,000,000 life insurance policy for the benefit of the partiesâ€™ emancipated son.Â  In conjunction with these assertions, Wife also requested Husband pay her attorneyâ€™s fees as well as interest for the seven-month period that Husband delayed in paying her share of the former marital home.Â  In his Answer, Husband denied the allegations and sought, as a counterclaim, for the court to find Wife in contempt for failing to comply with several provisions of the Agreement.
After a hearing, the family court issued an order in which it:Â  (1) found Husband failed to pay Wife, within the prescribed thirty-day period, her one-half interest in the former marital home; (2) ordered Husband to pay twelve percent interest for the seven-month period that he delayed in paying Wife her $175,000 share; (3) ordered Husband to submit to a medical examination so that Wife could procure a life insurance policy on Husband; (4) ordered Husband to provide proof of insurance coverage in which he indicated that the partiesâ€™ emancipated son was the beneficiary of a $2,000,000 life insurance policy; and (5) awarded Wife attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $2,700.[2]Â  Husband appeals. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202, 522 S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony. Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Contempt
Husband argues the family court erred in finding him in contempt and awarding Wife twelve percent interest for the seven months he delayed in paying Wife her interest in the marital home.Â  Although Husband admits that he failed to timely pay Wife her share, he contends the seven-month delay was not willful given Wife created the delay.Â  Specifically, he claims he was unable to immediately refinance the mortgage with which to pay Wife because, unbeknownst to him, Wife opened several credit accounts in his name.Â  Husband asserts financing was not approved until these accounts were resolved and Wife completed information required for refinancing.Â  
â€œThe power to punish for contempt is inherent in all courts and is essential to preservation of order in judicial proceedings.â€Â  In re Brown, 333 S.C. 414, 420, 511 S.E.2d 351, 355 (1998).Â  Contempt results from a partyâ€™s willful disobedience of a court order. Â Smith v. Smith, 359 S.C. 393, 396, 597 S.E.2d 188, 189 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2004) (A party may be found in contempt of court for the willful violation of a lawful court order.).Â  â€œA willful act is one which is â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€Â  Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)).Â  â€œ[B]efore a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€Â 
Widman, 348 S.C. at 119, 557 S.E.2d at 705.
â€œIn a proceeding for contempt for violation of a court order, the moving party must show the existence of a court order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with the order.â€Â  Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 501, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œOnce the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden then shifts to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to comply with the order.â€Â  Widman, 348 S.C. at 120, 557 S.E.2d at 705.
â€œA trial courtâ€™s determination regarding contempt is subject to reversal where it is based on findings that are without evidentiary support or where there has been an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Henderson v. Puckett, 316 S.C. 171, 173, 447 S.E.2d 871, 872 (Ct. App. 1994). â€œEven though a party is found to have violated a court order, the question of whether or not to impose sanctions remains a matter for the courtâ€™s discretion.â€Â  Hawkins, 359 S.C. at 503, 597 S.E.2d at 900.Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€Â  Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
We find the family court did not abuse its discretion in holding Husband in contempt.Â  Pursuant to the terms of the Agreement, Wife was permitted to reside in the marital home until the partiesâ€™ son enrolled in college.Â  Wife then had thirty days to vacate the home.Â  At that point, Husband was given the option of purchasing Wifeâ€™s one-half share of the equity in the marital home.Â  On January 1, 2002, Husband informed Wife that he intended to exercise this option.Â  In compliance with the Agreement, Wife vacated the marital home on September 17, 2002.Â  Thus, Husband was required to pay Wife her $175,000 equity share by October 17, 2002.Â  Husband did not, however, pay Wife until approximately seven months later on May 16, 2003. 
Although Husband violated the Agreement by failing to strictly comply with the thirty-day time period, we find Husband did not willfully cause the entire seven-month delay.Â  Husbandâ€™s mortgage broker testified Husband initiated the process to refinance the marital home in 2002.Â  He further testified there was a â€œshort delayâ€ in the process due to Husbandâ€™s credit score, which had been adversely affected by accounts Wife had apparently opened without Husbandâ€™s knowledge.Â  Additionally, he stated the remaining delay resulted because Wife did not sign over title to the property for several months after the quitclaim deed to the home was sent to her attorneyâ€™s office.Â  He testified the deed was sent to her attorney in October or November of 2002 and was returned to Husband in February 2003.Â  He stated there was no explanation for this delay and that the refinancing loan went through within three and a half weeks after the deed was received.Â  Wife also did not offer any explanation for the delay.
Because Wife did not expeditiously sign and return the quitclaim deed, we find Husband should not be penalized for the time period preceding his receipt of the deed in February 2003.Â  Accordingly, we modify the family courtâ€™s order and award Wife interest in the amount of $5,250, which represents the three-month delay between February 2003 and May 2003.[3]Â Â Â  
II.Â  Life Insurance
A.
Husband argues the family court erred in requiring him to submit to a medical examination in order that Wife could obtain a life insurance policy on his life.Â  Because Wifeâ€™s right to alimony had ended and all of the partiesâ€™ property claims had been settled, Husband asserts Wife no longer has an insurable interest in his life.Â  Thus, he contends he should not be forced to assist Wife in procuring the life insurance policy.Â  We find the court erred as a matter of law.
â€œWhether a property settlement agreement should be deemed to bar the divorced wife from receiving insurance benefits is a question of the construction of the agreement itself.â€ Estate of Revis v. Revis, 326 S.C. 470, 477, 484 S.E.2d 112, 116 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  When parties merge their settlement agreement into a decree, the family court transforms it from a contract between the parties to a decree of the court.Â  Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 214, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œThereafter, the agreement, as part of the court order, is fully subject to the family courtâ€™s authority to interpret and enforce its own decrees.â€ Id. at 214, 603 S.E.2d at 601-02.Â Â Â Â  
In order to analyze this issue, we must consider the controlling provision of the Agreement within the context of general insurance law regarding an insurable interest.Â  The Agreement states in pertinent part:

The husband and wife each grant to the other the right to maintain an insurable interest insuring the others [sic] life.Â  [Husband] has the right to insure [Wifeâ€™s] life he shall own the policy and be responsible for paying all the premiums.Â  [Wife] likewise may insure [Husbandâ€™s] life she will likewise own the policy and she will be responsible for the premiums.

In terms of what is required to obtain a policy of insurance, our appellate courts have stated:

In this country, it is a rule of law that one cannot insure for his own benefit the property of another in which he has no interest.Â  Insurance law accepts as a settled rule that an insured must possess an interest of some kind in the subject matter of the policy . . . . In order to recover on a policy of insurance, the insured must prove an insurable interest in the property both at the time the policy is issued and becomes effective and at the time of the loss.

Powell v. Insurance Co. of N. America, 285 S.C. 588, 589-90, 330 S.E.2d 550, 551-52 (Ct. App. 1985)(citations omitted); see Warren v. Pilgrim Health & Life Ins. Co., 217 S.C. 453, 456, 60 S.E.2d 891, 893 (1950)(â€œ[O]ne cannot obtain valid insurance upon the life of another in whom he has no insurable interest.â€).Â  Where an insurable interest does not exist at the time the contract for insurance was made, the insurance contract is void from its inception. Abraham v. New York Underwriters Ins. Co., 187 S.C. 70, 78, 196 S.E. 531, 534 (1938).Â  Additionally, this court has stated:

Policies will be maintained where it is clear that the party insured had an interest which would be injured in the event the peril insured against should happen.Â  It is not necessary to constitute an insurable interest that the interest be such that the event insured against would necessarily subject the insured to loss; it is sufficient that it might do so, and that pecuniary injury would be the natural consequence.

Benton & Rhodes, Inc. v. Boden, 310 S.C. 400, 404, 426 S.E.2d 823, 826 (Ct. App. 1993).

An â€œinsurable interestâ€ has been defined as follows:
It may be said, generally, that any one [sic] has an insurable interest in property who derives a benefit from its existence or would suffer loss from its destruction.Â  An insurable interest in property is any right, benefit or advantage arising out of or dependent thereon, or any liability in respect thereof, or any relation to or concern therein of such a nature that it might be so affected by the contemplated peril as to directly damnify the insured.

Benton, 310 S.C. at 403, 426 S.E.2d at 825 (quoting Crook v. Hartford Fire Ins. Co., 175 S.C. 42, 48, 178 S.E. 254, 257 (1935)); see Hack v. Metz, 173 S.C. 413, 418, 176 S.E. 314, 316 (1934)(â€œA person can have no insurable interest where his only right arises under a contract which he had no authority to make.â€).Â  â€œAn insurable interest is in the nature of an inchoate right, everpresent [sic] for perfection in those who possess the right, but never perfected until all legal requirements have been performed.â€Â  Ramey v. Carolina Life Ins. Co., 244 S.C. 16, 20, 135 S.E.2d 362, 364 (1964) (citation omitted).
When the parties entered into the Agreement, Wife was entitled to twenty-four months of alimony.Â  Because Wife was receiving alimony, she had an insurable interest in Husbandâ€™s life.Â  See Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 548, 615 S.E.2d 98, 106 (2005) (â€œIt is a settled proposition of law that a former wife who is entitled to alimony has an insurable interest in her former husbandâ€™s life.Â  The parties in a divorce proceeding may agree, in a private agreement subsequently merged into the courtâ€™s order, that a payor spouse shall maintain life insurance to secure an award of alimony.â€)(citation omitted).Â  However, once this obligation ended, Wife no longer had an insurable interest nor, can we discern from the record, a pecuniary interest.[4]Â  See Roberts v. Southwestern Life Ins. Co., 244 S.W.2d 302, 307 (Tex. Civ. App. 1951) (recognizing â€œupon divorce and termination of insurable interest, a policy cannot be beneficially owned by one divorced spouse on life of the other on basis of past relationshipâ€).
Significantly, this case does not present a scenario where Husband seeks to eliminate Wife as a beneficiary for an existing policy.Â  Instead, Wife is attempting to obtain a new life insurance policy on Husband after his financial obligation to her has ceased.Â  Cf. Estate of Revis, 326 S.C. at 477, 484 S.E.2d at 116 (â€œAlthough a divorce does not itself affect a beneficiaryâ€™s right to insurance proceeds, it is generally recognized that a beneficiary may contract this right away through a separation or property settlement agreement, even if the beneficiary designation is not formally changed.â€); Duncan v. Investors Diversified Servs., Inc., 285 S.C. 467, 470, 330 S.E.2d 295, 296 (1985) (stating â€œdivorce does not of itself operate to defeat the beneficiaryâ€™s claimâ€); Hughes v. Scholl, 900 S.W.2d 606, 607 (Ky. 1995) (recognizing â€œdivorce alone does not disturb a former spouseâ€™s status as an insurance policy beneficiaryâ€).
Furthermore, we believe ordering Husband to submit to a medical examination against his will, i.e., forcing him to consent, where there is no insurable interest would violate public policy.Â  See Ramey, 244 S.C. at 22, 135 S.E.2d at 365 (It is well settled that â€œ[a] policy of insurance taken out on the life of another without his knowledge or consent is void and against public policy in that it might be a fruitful source of crime.â€)(emphasis added); Hack, 173 S.C. at 418, 176 S.E. at 316 (â€œIt has been broadly stated that insurance taken out on the life of another, without the latterâ€™s consent is against public policy and void.â€)(citation omitted).
Additionally, we reject Wifeâ€™s assertion that Husband consented to a perpetual insurable interest by entering into the Agreement.Â  See Abraham, 187 S.C. at 78, 196 S.E. at 534 (recognizing â€œ[n]either the doctrine of waiver nor the doctrine of estoppel can be invoked to give legalityâ€ to a contract where there exists no insurable interest, and thus, is absolutely null and void from its inception).
Because Wife lacked an insurable interest, we find ordering Husband to consent to a medical examination would violate public policy.Â  Accordingly, we hold the family court erred regarding the life insurance policy for the benefit of Wife.Â  See Elmore v. Life Ins. Co. of Virginia, 187 S.C. 504, 508-09, 198 S.E. 5, 7 (1938) (â€œOne cannot, by his own act, procure a valid enforceable policy of insurance for his own benefit upon the life of another in which he has no insurable interest; that such a contract of insurance is void in its inception and unenforceable on grounds of public policy, being a mere wagering contract.â€)(citation omitted); Henderson v. Life Ins. Co. of Virginia, 176 S.C. 100, 113-14, 179 S.E. 680, 685-86 (1935)(â€œThe law does not allow one who has no insurable interest in the life of another, to insure it for his benefit, for the reason that it is a mere wager and holds out a temptation to fraud, the insurer having no interest in the life of the assured and having a direct interest in his death.â€) (citations omitted).Â  Once the obligation of support is extinguished there is no insurable interest of right and the acquisition of any new insurance policy must be with the consent of the insured spouse or former spouse. 
B.
Husband argues the family court erred in ordering additional requirements for the life insurance policy on Husbandâ€™s life for the benefit of the partiesâ€™ emancipated son.
As evidenced by the terms of the Agreement, Husband owned a $2,000,000 life insurance policy issued on March 3, 1993, which designated the partiesâ€™ son as the beneficiary.Â  The Agreement further provided that Husband was required to provide Wife with written documentation verifying that son remained as beneficiary.Â  In her contempt action, Wife requested the family court order Husband to provide her with proof of coverage and beneficiary designation.Â  She also sought proof that Husbandâ€™s cash withdrawal from the policy had not reduced the face amount.Â  In ruling on this issue, the family court held that Wife could request, and Husband must provide, verification of insurance coverage and beneficiary designation at reasonable periodic intervals.Â  The court also limited Husband to a total of $295,826 in withdrawals from this policy and further found the policy should remain in effect with no time limitations.Â  
We find, and Wife concedes, the court granted relief beyond that which was requested in Wifeâ€™s pleadings.Â  During the hearing, Husband informed the court that the $2,000,000 life insurance policy was still in effect and the partiesâ€™ son was the designated beneficiary.Â  Because this information sufficiently satisfied the relief Wife requested in her pleadings, the courtâ€™s additional rulings regarding the policy constituted error.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the court with respect to ordering Husband:Â  (1) to maintain the policy in apparent perpetuity; (2) to provide Wife or the son continuing coverage and beneficiary information; and (3) to limit his cash withdrawals from the policy.Â  See Bass v. Bass, 272 S.C. 177, 180, 249 S.E.2d 905, 906 (1978) (holding the family court cannot award relief that is not contemplated by the pleadings). 
III.            
Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
Finally, Husband asserts the family court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  He argues the award of attorneyâ€™s fees should be vacated if this court rules in his favor on the issues that he has raised on appeal.
â€œAn award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial court.â€ Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider: (1) the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by counsel; (3) the respective financial conditions of the parties; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  The factors the family court should consider in awarding reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs include:Â  (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) the professional standing of counsel; (4) the contingency of compensation; (5) the beneficial results obtained; and (6) the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).
Although we have ruled in favor of Husband on several issues, this alone is not dispositive of our decision regarding the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  First, Wife prevailed on several issues at trial.Â  Secondly, Husbandâ€™s failure to comply with the terms of the Agreement necessitated Wife filing the action for contempt.Â  For example, Husband concedes he delayed in transferring the partiesâ€™ mountain property and beach property to Wife.Â  Finally, the court properly considered the requisite factors and exercised its discretion in limiting Wifeâ€™s award to $2,700 despite her request for $3,700.Â  Accordingly, we decline to vacate Wifeâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we affirm the decision of the family court holding Husband in contempt and awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We reverse the courtâ€™s order requiring Husband to submit to a medical examination so that Wife could procure an insurance policy on his life.Â  Additionally, we reverse the courtâ€™s decision ordering Husband to provide additional information to Wife concerning a life insurance policy for the benefit of the partiesâ€™ emancipated son.Â  Finally, we modify the courtâ€™s order with respect to the amount of the award of post-judgment interest to Wife.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND MODIFIED IN PART.
GOOLSBY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  We note the family court ruled on several other issues regarding the Agreement.Â  However, we need not list or address them given these rulings are not pertinent to the instant appeal.
[3]Â  $175,000 x 12% x 3/12 = $5,250.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(B) (Supp. 2004) (â€œAll money decrees and judgments of courts enrolled or entered shall draw interest according to law.Â  The legal interest is at the rate of twelve percent a year.â€).Â  We note the General Assembly amended this subsection on March 21, 2005.Â  This amendment, however, applies to all judgments entered on or after July 1, 2005.Â  Act No. 27, 2005 S.C. Acts 119.
[4]Â  We note Wife contends that she has an insurable interest in Husbandâ€™s life because she is potentially liable for any debt associated with Husbandâ€™s medical practice.Â  We disagree with this contention given Wife, in the Agreement, specifically waived any interest in Husbandâ€™s practice and Husband agreed to indemnify Wife for any payments associated with the practice.Â  Moreover, Wifeâ€™s claim of potential liability is vague at best.Â  She offers no specific debt or liability she has as a result of Husbandâ€™s medical practice.

description: Gore appeals the circuit court decision to affirm the magistrate court's verdict in favor of A&I, arguing: (1) a new trial should have been granted because the magistrate's return violated statutory mandates; (2) the return was prepared ex parte; (3) the tapes of the original proceeding were lost; and (4) a continuance should have been granted by the circuit court. Gene McCain Connell, Jr., of Surfside Beach, for Appellant.
Daniel J. MacDonald, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Bobby Gore appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision to affirm the magistrate court verdict in favor of A&I.Â  He argues a new trial should have been granted because the magistrateâ€™s return violated statutory mandates, the return was prepared ex parte, and the tapes of the original proceeding were lost.Â  He also argues the circuit court erred in failing to grant a continuance.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Gore owned three apartments at the Sun Deck Horizontal Property Regime.Â  The master deed provided that apartment owners were responsible for any problems with interior walls and for maintenance and repairs on appliances and equipment â€œincluding any fixtures and/or their connections required to provide water, light, power, telephone, sewage, and sanitary service to his apartment.â€Â  The deed further provided that the Sun Deck Horizontal Property Regime Homeowners Association (â€œHOAâ€) was responsible for maintaining and repairing the common elements of the regime, including all plumbing located in the common elements.Â  â€œCommon elementsâ€ was defined to include load-bearing walls and pipes.Â  
Gore began experiencing water infiltration problems in his downstairs apartment, Apartment C.Â  He contacted A&I to locate and repair the leak, and A&I subcontracted Four Star Plumbing to perform the work.Â  After Four Star Plumbing employee Steve Beatty cut holes in the wall and ceiling of Apartment C, the source of the water damage to Apartment C was eventually determined to be a leaky washing machine valve in Goreâ€™s upstairs apartment, Apartment H.Â  The valve was replaced, and the leaking stopped.Â  Four Star Plumbing also suggested that the washing machine valve in Edward Edelenâ€™s adjacent apartment be replaced.Â  Edelen agreed and paid for the repairs.Â  After replacing the valve in Apartment H but prior to patching and repairing the walls and ceiling in Goreâ€™s apartments, A&I requested payment from Gore.Â  Gore refused, believing the damages were to internal water pipes that were part of the common area of the regime.Â  Thus, he believed the repairs were the responsibility of the HOA.Â  Gore refused A&I further access to his apartments to complete the repairs to the ceiling and walls.Â  
A&I eventually brought an action in magistrate court against Gore, Edelen as president of the HOA, and the HOA for the money owed on the repairs.Â  The day of the trial, Gore orally requested a continuance and a jury trial, and the magistrate denied both requests.Â  Several parties testified before the magistrate, including Lenny Green, an estimator for A&I; Rod Tressle, an employee of A&I; Edelen; and Steve Beatty, employee of Four Star Plumbing.Â  Green, Tressle, and Edelen testified that prior to agreeing to perform the work, they were all present at a meeting held by A&I with Gore to establish the terms.Â  According to Green, Tressle, and Edelen, Gore agreed to pay for the work necessary to investigate and repair the leak.Â  Gore attempted to cross-examine Edelen regarding other litigation in which Edelen was involved, but the magistrate refused to allow the questioning.[1]Â  Gore also testified, denying the meeting or the agreement ever took place.Â  
After hearing testimony from the parties, the magistrate determined that Gore made a direct agreement with A&I to pay for the repair costs.Â  Thus, the magistrate found that it was irrelevant if the master deed provided that the particular repairs were something for which the HOA must pay.Â  The magistrate found for A&I and ordered Gore to pay $2,257.74, plus interest and court costs.Â  
Gore filed his notice of appeal to the circuit court, arguing that the magistrate court erred in failing to:Â  (1) grant him a jury trial and a continuance; (2) allow him to cross-examine Edelen regarding past litigation; and (3) hold the HOA responsible for the charges due on the repairs.Â  The magistrate court contacted counsel for A&I and informed him that the tapes of the magistrate court trial could not be transcribed.Â  The magistrate court requested that A&Iâ€™s counsel draft a proposed return.Â  Counsel for A&I drafted a proposed return and submitted it to the magistrate court.Â  The magistrate signed the return and submitted it to the circuit court.Â  Goreâ€™s counsel was not contacted by the magistrate court regarding the problems with the tapes, was not asked to submit a proposed return, and was not served with a copy of the return.Â  
A hearing was held before the circuit court on July 21, 2004.Â  Goreâ€™s counsel objected that a return had not been filed in the case.Â  Counsel for A&I informed the court that the magistrate court contacted him to prepare a submittal for the return because the tapes of the trial were of such poor quality they could not be transcribed and the magistrate â€œwas going to have to create a return from his notes.â€Â  Goreâ€™s counsel was then provided a copy of the return and given an opportunity to review it prior to arguing the appeal.Â  Goreâ€™s counsel argued the return was insufficient because it did not note that the magistrate prohibited Gore from cross-examining Edelen regarding other lawsuits in which he was involved.Â  Gore argued he never made an agreement to pay for the repairs.Â  He also argued the master deed to Sun Deck Condominiums provided that Gore would not be responsible for damage to common areas, Gore should not have been liable to pay A&I even if he had made an agreement otherwise, and the HOA was responsible for the payments.Â  
The circuit court found no abuse of discretion for the magistrate to deny cross-examination of Edelen regarding other lawsuits.Â  The court ruled from the bench that there was adequate testimony to support the magistrateâ€™s findings regarding Goreâ€™s agreement to be responsible for the repair charges.Â  Finally, the court held that the magistrate did not abuse his discretion in denying Goreâ€™s motions for a jury trial and a continuance.Â  The appeal was dismissed, and a form order was signed that day.Â  
On August 24, 2004, Gore filed a notice of appeal from the July 21, 2004 form order.Â  A formal written order outlining the circuit courtâ€™s decision to affirm was filed August 19, 2004.Â  The notice of appeal does not refer to the formal August 19, 2004 order.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the magistrate court, the circuit court may make its own findings of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-170 (1985) (â€œIn giving judgment the court may affirm or reverse the judgment of the court below, in whole or in part, as to any or all the parties and for errors of law or fact.â€).Â  Where the circuit court has affirmed the magistrate court decision, this court looks to whether the circuit court order is â€œcontrolled by an error of law or is unsupported by the facts.â€Â  Parks v. Characters Night Club, 345 S.C. 484, 490, 548 S.E.2d 605, 608 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œThe Court of Appeals will presume that an affirmance by a Circuit Court of a magistrateâ€™s judgment was made upon the merits where the testimony is sufficient to sustain the magistrateâ€™s judgment and there are no facts that show the affirmance was influenced by an error of law.â€Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Magistrateâ€™s Return
Gore argues the circuit court erred in failing to reverse the magistrate and order a new trial because:Â  (1) the return did not comply with section 18-7-60 of the Code of Laws; (2) it was error for the magistrate to direct A&Iâ€™s counsel to prepare the return ex parte; and (3) the judgment should have been vacated when the tapes were insufficient.Â  We disagree. 
A. Compliance with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-60 (1985)
Gore asserts the magistrateâ€™s return failed to comply with section 18-7-60 because the section requires the magistrate, not a party, to prepare and file the return.Â  He argues that public policy requires the magistrate, as an unbiased judicial official, must prepare the return.Â  Because A&I prepared the return, he argues the circuit court should have ordered a new trial.Â  
In order to evaluate the effect of this section, we must apply statutory construction rules.Â  The words of the statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  If a statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning, â€œthe rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose another meaning.â€Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  
When a party appeals to the circuit court from a magistrate court order, the magistrate court â€œshall thereupon, after ten days and within thirty days after service of the notice of appeal, make a return to the appellate court of the testimony, proceedings and judgment and file it in the appellate court.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-60 (1985).Â  If the return is deemed defective, â€œthe appellate court may direct a further or amended return as often as may be necessary and may compel a compliance with its order.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-80 (1985); see Chapman v. Computers, Parts, & Repairs, Inc., 334 S.C. 387, 390, 513 S.E.2d 120, 122 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding that where the magistrateâ€™s return is inadequate, the appropriate remedy is for the circuit court to direct the magistrate to file an amended return instead of remanding for a new trial).Â  
Section 18-7-60 requires the magistrate to â€œmake a return to the appellate courtâ€ within a certain time period, but it does not indicate it would be error for the magistrate to seek assistance in drafting the return.Â  Because a plain reading of this section does not forbid the magistrate from seeking assistance where, as here, there were problems with the recording of the trial, we find such consultations do not violate the statute.Â  In this case, there is no question that the magistrate filed a return, and thus, the magistrate complied with the statute.Â  
Further, Goreâ€™s only complaint below regarding the sufficiency of the return was the failure to include the magistrateâ€™s refusal to allow him to cross-examine Edelen about other litigation.Â  Gore sought to use cross-examination to show that Edelen was not credible.Â  The circuit court found the return was adequate for reviewing Goreâ€™s grounds on appeal.Â  The court further found that because cross-examination is a matter within a courtâ€™s discretion, the magistrate did not err in refusing to allow Gore to cross-examine Edelen about something not normally allowed for impeachment purposes.Â  We agree with this finding.Â Â  
Additionally, the circuit court found in the formal order that Edelenâ€™s testimony was cumulative to other witnesses regarding Goreâ€™s promise to pay for the charges associated with the repairs.Â  Challenging the credibility of Edelen would not change the testimony of the other witnesses regarding Goreâ€™s promise.Â  See Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Center Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 26, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005) (finding that to warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and that there was a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the evidence or lack thereof).Â  Thus, we agree with the circuit court that Gore can point to no prejudice suffered by the failure to cross-examine Edelen.Â  
Finally, we find that if the circuit court had found the return was deficient, the appropriate remedy would have been for the court to request an amended return from the magistrate, not order a new trial.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-80 (1985); Chapman, 334 S.C. at 390, 513 S.E.2d at 122.Â  Here, the court found the return was sufficient to allow it to address Goreâ€™s issues on appeal.Â  Gore does not appeal this finding.Â  Accordingly, the finding that the return was sufficient is the law of the case.Â  ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P., 327 S.C. at 241, 489 S.E.2d at 472.Â  
Because the magistrate complied with the mandates of section 18-7-60 by filing a return and there was no basis to support ordering a new trial, we find no error with the circuit courtâ€™s decision to affirm the magistrate court and to deny a new trial.Â  
B.Â  Ex Parte communications
Gore argues the magistrate erred in allowing A&Iâ€™s counsel to prepare the return ex parte, and the prejudice he suffered from such a communication mandated a new trial.Â  
Ex parte communications are strongly disfavored.Â  Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 623, 576 S.E.2d 156, 162 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  However, â€œprejudice must be shown to obtain a reversal on this ground.â€Â  Id.; see Burgess v. Stern, 311 S.C. 326, 331, 428 S.E.2d 880, 884 (1993) (finding no prejudice from a judgeâ€™s ex parte communication with one party for assistance in drafting a final order where the judgeâ€™s order was supported by the evidence).Â  â€œWhile this Court explicitly condemns ex parte communications, we do not adopt, per se, the view that all orders consequently emanating therefrom in part or in whole are rendered invalid.â€Â  Burgess, 311 S.C. at 331, 428 S.E.2d at 884.Â  
Initially, we note that this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Although Gore questioned the validity pursuant to statute of allowing A&I to draft the return, Gore never argued before the circuit court that he was entitled to a new trial due to the ex parte communication.Â  Issues not raised to or ruled upon by the lower court are not preserved for appellate review.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000).Â  
In any event, we find Gore did not suffer any prejudice from the ex parte communications.Â  The return was drafted well after the magistrate issued his written order.Â  The return contained much of the same language as found in the order, with the addition of the summaries of testimony.Â  Further, although the return failed to indicate that the magistrate refused to allow cross-examination of Edelen regarding other litigation, Edelenâ€™s testimony was merely cumulative to that of other witnesses.Â  Thus, discrediting Edelen would not have affected the outcome of the trial.Â  Gore did not dispute the accuracy of the rest of the return, and he failed to show that he was prejudiced by the ex parte communication.Â  
Although the unfortunate ex parte communication between the magistrate and A&Iâ€™s counsel is strongly disfavored, we find no prejudice suffered by Gore.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err by not granting a new trial and by affirming the magistrate court. 
C.Â  Lost tapes
Citing McKinley Music v. Glymph, 100 S.C. 200, 84 S.E. 715 (1915), Gore argues the circuit court erred in failing to grant him a new trial because the tapes of the magistrate court proceeding were lost.Â  He argues that because the magistrate does not have records to make an amended return, the circuit court should have granted a new trial.Â  
In McKinley Music, the magistrate court found in favor of the defendant, and the plaintiff appealed the verdict to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court reversed, ordering a new trial because the defendantâ€™s testimony â€œwas not fully taken down.â€Â  McKinley, 100 S.C. at 202, 84 S.E. at 716.Â  The supreme court affirmed, finding that an â€œamended or further return by the magistrate would not have been effective to supply testimony which had not been â€˜taken down.â€™â€Â  Id.
We find McKinley does not apply in the present case.Â  The circuit court held the return was sufficient to address the issues Gore raised on appeal.Â  Gore does not appeal that finding, and, as previously discussed, it is the law of the case.Â  The return did not leave out any testimony.Â  The only information omitted from the return was the magistrateâ€™s decision on questioning.Â  Further, there is no evidence in the record that the magistrate lost the tapes of the proceeding or his notes.Â  The arguments before the circuit court were that the magistrate had his notes and poor quality tapes, but he wanted submissions from counsel to aid him in preparing the return.Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court did not err in refusing to grant a new trial pursuant to McKinley.Â Â Â Â  
II.Â  Continuance
Gore argues the circuit court erred by requiring him to review the return and argue the case at the hearing despite the fact that the return was never properly served on him.Â  We disagree.
This issue is not properly before us.Â  Gore did not request a continuance when he was given a copy of the magistrateâ€™s return for the first time at the appellate hearing before the circuit court.Â  Because the lower court was not given the opportunity to consider whether Gore was entitled to a continuance, this issue is not preserved.Â  Staubes, 339 S.C. at 412, 529 S.E.2d at 546 (holding issues not raised to and ruled upon by the lower court are not preserved for appellate review).Â Â  
In any event, Goreâ€™s argument also fails on the merits.Â  The decision to grant or deny a continuance is a matter within the lower courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Graybar Elec. Co. v. Rice, 287 S.C. 518, 520, 339 S.E.2d 883, 884 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  Absent an abuse of discretion, the courtâ€™s decision to deny a continuance will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Hamm v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 312 S.C. 238, 241, 439 S.E.2d 852, 853 (1994).Â  
Nothing in the record indicates that Gore was prejudiced by going forward with his appellate argument before the circuit court.Â  He was given time to review the magistrateâ€™s return, and he informed the court that he excepted to the absence of the magistrateâ€™s ruling on cross-examination.Â  Despite the returnâ€™s failure to include a reference to the magistrateâ€™s ruling, the circuit court was able to rule upon Goreâ€™s complaint on appeal concerning this issue.Â  The court found that because the decision to allow certain questioning was discretionary, there was no error for the magistrate to prohibit Goreâ€™s questioning about unrelated litigation.Â  Reviewing these facts, we find no abuse of discretion in the failure to grant a continuance.
CONCLUSION
We find the magistrateâ€™s return complies with section 18-7-60, Gore was not prejudiced by ex parte contact between the magistrate and A&Iâ€™s counsel, and the circuit court did not err in failing to grant a new trial pursuant to McKinley due to problems with the magistrateâ€™s tapes.Â  Further, we find no error with the circuit courtâ€™s failure to grant a continuance. 
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the magistrate courtâ€™s verdict is
 AFFIRMED.[2]
 GOOLSBY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  This fact is not found in the magistrateâ€™s return and is an issue on appeal.Â  Gore argued before the circuit court that the return failed to note the attempt to cross-examine Edelen.Â  Counsel for A&I did not dispute the fact that the attempt to cross-examine Edelen occurred or the failure of the return to include that fact.Â Â Â  
[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
