text:
State v. Washington


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Cornelius Washington, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4033
Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed October 17, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant. 
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Cornelius Washington appeals his conviction for murder, raising two evidentiary issues.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Washington was involved in a ten-year relationship with Andreia Cropper, ending in April or May of 2002.Â  After the breakup, Cropper met Roy Cotman, a security guard.Â  On August 28, 2002, Cropper and Cotman spent the day together, looking at apartments and fishing.Â  When Cotman drove Cropper home that evening, Washington was waiting in the parking area.Â  Soon after Cotman and Cropperâ€™s arrival, Washington stabbed Cotman.Â  Cropper and Washington testified to different versions of the events surrounding the stabbing.Â  
Cropperâ€™s Version of the Facts
As Cropper exited Cotmanâ€™s vehicle, Washington hit Cropperâ€™s head with his fist.Â  Cropper noticed knives in Washingtonâ€™s hands.Â  Cropper ran to the door of her motherâ€™s home, knocked, and kicked the door.Â  Washington stated, â€œThereâ€™s no need knocking on the door because your mama, she ainâ€™t there.Â  Sheâ€™s over at your auntâ€™s house.â€Â  Washington then began yelling at Cotman.Â  Cropper told Washington to leave Cotman alone â€œbecause he had nothing to do with it.â€Â  Washington leaned into the driverâ€™s side of Cotmanâ€™s vehicle.Â  Cropper grabbed the back of Washingtonâ€™s shirt and pulled him out of the car.Â  Cropper next saw Cotman lying on the ground behind the car with blood on his shoulders.Â  
Washingtonâ€™s Version of the Facts
When Cropper exited Cotmanâ€™s vehicle, Washington stated, â€œOh, still messing around with him, huh?â€Â  Cotman backed out of the parking area, but returned because Cropper and Washington began arguing.Â  Cotman opened the door of his car and said, â€œLeave her alone.â€Â  Cotman exited his vehicle, turned on the interior light of the vehicle, and bent over to look under the seats.Â  Washington said, â€œI hope youâ€™re not going to get a weapon to hurt me.â€Â  Cotman did not reply.Â  Washington repeated, â€œI hope you not be looking for no weapon to hurt me with.â€Â  Cotman opened the back door of his vehicle and started searching under the back seats.Â  Washington said, â€œMan, I not gonna let you get nothing out of that car to hurt me with.â€Â  After warning Cotman a few more times, Washington unbuckled his knife and walked toward the car.Â  Cotman jumped up and turned around.Â  Washington began â€œswingingâ€ his arms at Cotman because he thought Cotman might have a gun.Â  After Cropper pulled Washington away from Cotman, Cotman walked toward the trunk and fell to the ground.Â  Washington testified he did not realize Cotman was injured until Cotman â€œfell on his face.â€Â  Before leaving the scene, Washington placed Cotman into the vehicle.Â  
Other Facts
When police officers arrived at the scene, they found Cotman bleeding profusely and lying face down in the back seat of his car. Â An EMS paramedic testified Cotman was not breathing and had no pulse. Â EMS transported Cotman to the hospital where he was pronounced dead.
A forensic pathologist testified Cotman suffered a stab wound above the collarbone, a stab wound on his chin, and two cuts on his right forearm. Â 
Corporal Scott Kiblock of the Charleston Police Department was present at the crime scene. Â Kiblock drove Cropper to the Charleston Police Department headquarters to obtain her written statement.Â  The interview process began approximately ninety minutes after the stabbing.Â  During the interview, Cropper was noticeably upset and crying. Â 
Officer Jeffrey Miller, a crime scene technician, investigated the scene and found blood on the front passenger seat, on the rear passenger seat, down the passenger side of the vehicle, and on the trunk. Â Officer Miller found no blood on the driverâ€™s seat or the interior panel of the driverâ€™s side. Â In addition, Officer Miller found a gun and a knife in the trunk of the vehicle. Â The gun was issued to Cotman in connection with his employment as a security guard.Â  
Police officers found Washington shortly after the murder and arrested him.Â  The officers found two knives on Washington. Â One knife had Cotmanâ€™s blood on the blade.Â  
The case proceeded to trial on August 25, 2003.Â  Cropper, Washington, Officer Miller, Corporal Kiblock, and several other witnesses testified. 
The jury convicted Washington of murder.Â  We affirm.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A trial courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. McLeod, 362 S.C. 73, 79, 606 S.E.2d 215, 218-19 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
LAW/ ANALYSIS
I.Â  Exclusion of Gun and Knife
Washington argues the trial court erred in refusing to admit evidence of the gun and knife found in the trunk of Cotmanâ€™s vehicle, alleging it was relevant to his claim of self-defense. Â We disagree.Â  
Relevant evidence is â€œevidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  â€œTo establish self-defense, the defendant must establish:Â  (1) he was without fault in bringing on the difficulty; (2) he actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) a reasonably prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage would have entertained the same belief; and (4) he had no other probable means of avoiding the danger.â€Â  State v. Long, 325 S.C. 59, 62, 480 S.E.2d 62, 63 (1997).Â  
Cropper proffered testimony about the gun and knife.Â  Cropper testified Cotman carried a firearm in his vehicle because he was a security guard. Â She further testified Cotmanâ€™s gun was in the trunk of his car on the day of the murder because â€œhe knew that I didnâ€™t like guns.â€Â  When asked whether Cotman was armed with the gun at any point, Cropper responded:Â  â€œNo, it was in the trunk of his car.â€Â  She added she never saw the trunk open. Â Cropper had no knowledge concerning the knife found in the trunk. Â Officer Miller also proffered testimony, stating he found the gun and knife in the trunk of Cotmanâ€™s vehicle.Â  
Washington testified Cotman exited his vehicle and searched underneath the front and back seats.Â  Washington stated:Â  â€œmost people, like my grandfather and them, they carry they gun under the car seat, you know.Â  So I donâ€™t see no other reason . . . for him to be . . . [looking] under the seat.â€ Â 
The trial court refused to admit testimony regarding the weapons found in the trunk of the vehicle on the ground of relevancy.Â  The trial court found:Â  â€œThe Defense . . . has not been precluded from presenting a defense of self-defense or from presenting evidence of self-defense.Â  The Court has merely made a ruling regarding the admissibility of the gun and knife that were found in a locked trunk.â€Â  The trial court concluded the weapons were not â€œrelevant or probative to any issue in this case.â€Â  
Washington contends evidence of the gun and the knife in the trunk was relevant to show he reasonably believed he was in imminent danger.Â  There is no evidence in the record, however, indicating Washington knew Cotman had weapons in his trunk on the day of the stabbing, nor is there evidence Washington was aware Cotman ever carried a weapon in his trunk.Â  Furthermore, there is no evidence that Cotman searched his trunk prior to the stabbing.Â  In fact, there was blood on the trunk, indicating that when Cotman approached the trunk, he had already been stabbed.Â  
Finally, Washington presented his claim of self-defense.Â  He testified to his own experience and his grandfatherâ€™s custom of keeping weapons in vehicles.Â  He explained his belief, at the time of the incident, that Cotman might have a weapon in the car.Â  The trial court charged the jury on the law of self-defense.Â  Under these facts, we find no prejudicial error by the trial court in excluding evidence regarding weapons found in Cotmanâ€™s trunk.Â  
II.Â  Hearsay, the Excited Utterance Exception, and Testimonial Evidence
Washington also argues the trial court erred in allowing Corporal Kiblock to testify regarding the contents of Cropperâ€™s written statement.Â  The trial court found the statement qualified as an excited utterance.Â  Washington argues the trial court erred in admitting the testimony because it was hearsay, was not an excited utterance, and it improperly bolstered Cropperâ€™s testimony.Â  We find no reversible error.Â  
â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™ is a statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  Hearsay is inadmissible as evidence unless an exception applies.Â  State v. Townsend, 321 S.C. 55, 59, 467 S.E.2d 138, 141 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  One exception is the excited utterance exception.Â  Rule 803, SCRE.Â  
â€œThree elements must be met to show a statement is an excited utterance:Â (1) the statement must relate to a startling event or
condition; (2) the statement must have been made while the declarant was under the stress of the excitement; and (3) the stress must have been caused by the startling event or condition.Â  The court must consider the totality of the circumstances in determining whether a statement falls within the excited utterance
exception.â€Â  State v. Davis, 364 S.C. 364, 402-03, 613 S.E.2d 760, 780-81 (Ct. App. 2005) (internal citations omitted).Â  The rationale for the excited utterance exception lies in the
special reliability accorded to a statement uttered in spontaneous excitement that suspends the declarantâ€™s powers of reflection and fabrication.Â  Id. at 403, 613 S.E.2d at 781.Â  The passage of time between the startling event and the hearsay statement is not necessarily a dispositive factor.Â  State v. Blackburn, 271 S.C. 324, 328, 247 S.E.2d 334, 336 (decided prior to the adoption of the Rules of Evidence and discussing the â€œexcited utteranceâ€ exception as res gestae; noting that a time interval of over one hour, and up to eleven hours, did not necessarily eliminate a statement as part of the res gestae).Â  
In the instant case, the stabbing was clearly a startling event.Â  There is evidence Cropper was under stress caused by the stabbing at the time she made her statement.Â  Corporal Kiblock testified in camera that the statement began approximately ninety minutes after the incident.Â  According to Kiblock, Cropper was â€œextremely upset and distraughtâ€ as she gave her statement.Â  She cried throughout the statement, stopping at times to regain her composure.Â  Finally, the stress was caused by the startling event of her ex-boyfriend stabbing her new boyfriend.Â  
In addition, although Washington argues that a â€œnarrativeâ€ statement given to police is inadmissible under this exception, numerous South Carolina cases have held otherwise.Â  See State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 43, 515 S.E.2d 525, 530 (1999) (providing an extensive list of instances in which the court has admitted statements to police pursuant to the former common law res gestae exception).Â  
Washington relies in part on Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36 (2004), an important case decided by the United States Supreme Court subsequent to Washingtonâ€™s trial.Â  However, we find Crawford does not apply.Â  In Crawford, the prosecution introduced tape-recorded statements made to police by Crawfordâ€™s wife, Sylvia.Â  Id. at 38-40.Â  Resorting to the application of the marital privilege, which generally bars a spouse from testifying without the other spouseâ€™s consent, Sylvia did not testify at trial, and was therefore considered an unavailable witness.Â  Id. at 40.Â  On appeal, the court concluded that when the declarant is unavailable, hearsay statements that are testimonial in nature can be admitted into evidence only when the declarant has previously been subjected to cross-examination.Â  Id. at 68.Â  The courtâ€™s analysis was rooted in a defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment[1] right to confrontation.Â  In the instant case, had Cropper been unavailable as a witness at trial, Crawford would be controlling and the admission of her statement likely error.[2]Â  However, because Cropper was available and did in fact testify at trial, a confrontation clause analysis under Crawford is not required. 
We agree with Washington that Cropperâ€™s statement constituted hearsay.Â  However, we find, like the trial court, that the statement qualified for admission under the excited utterance exception.Â  Finally, we find the statement did not improperly bolster Cropperâ€™s testimony, as her statement contained numerous differences compared to her direct testimony.Â  See Ingle v. State, 348 S.C. 467, 474, 560 S.E.2d 401, 404 (2002); Jolly v. State, 314 S.C. 17, 21, 443 S.E.2d 566, 569 (1994).Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

[1] Â Â â€œIn all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right . . . to be confronted with the witnesses against him. . . .â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. VI.
[2]  Â Â Although the Supreme Court failed to define what constitutes a testimonial statement, it concluded, â€œ[s]tatements taken by police officers in the course of interrogations are . . . testimonial under even a narrow standard.â€Â  Crawford, 541 U.S. at 52.

description: In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, the appellate entity decides the following issues: (1) did the claimant file his occupational disease claim within the applicable statute of limitations set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-40; (2) is the appeal premature because the circuit court order is not a final judgment; and (3) did the circuit court properly remand the case to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission for determination of an allocation between compensable and non-compensable causes in accordance with S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 42-11-90 and 42-11-100.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Edwin H. Brown, Appellant/Respondent,
v.
Greenwood Mills, Inc., Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. Â 4034
Heard October 12, 2005 â€“ Filed October 24, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Linda Byars McKenzie, of Greenville, for Appellant-Respondent.
Roy R. Hemphill, of Greenwood, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  


 ANDERSON, J.:Â  The workersâ€™ compensation commission affirmed the order of the single commissioner awarding benefits to Edwin H. Brown (Brown) for an occupational lung disease, byssinosis, which Brown claims he developed from working with cotton for many years at Greenwood Mills, Inc. (Greenwood).Â  The circuit court affirmed the commissionâ€™s ruling that Brownâ€™s claim was within the statute of limitations, but declared the commission should have allocated a portion of Brownâ€™s disease to his long history of cigarette smoking, a non-compensable cause.Â  Therefore, the circuit court remanded the case to the commission for allocation.Â  Both parties appealed. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Greenwood employed Brown from 1966 to 1982 and again from 1983 until 1998.Â  As a Greenwood employee, Brown worked primarily with cotton in the carding, spinning, and preparation departments.Â  While at work, he frequently was exposed to cotton dust.Â  Brown, who smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for approximately forty-five years, stopped working in 1998 due to breathing problems.
Brownâ€™s respiratory difficulties started sometime around the early 1990s.Â  At that time, Greenwood began performing two breathing tests a year on Brown in order to evaluate and monitor his breathing troubles.Â  Although he quit smoking in February of 1995, Brown continued to suffer from shortness of breath, difficulty walking, and fatigue.Â  In December 1997, Greenwood referred Brown to Dr. Cobb for treatment.Â  
Dr. Cobb diagnosed Brown as having hyper-expanded lungs, a depressed diaphragm, and obstructive lung disease.Â  Initially, Dr. Cobb opined that Brownâ€™s obstructive lung disease was â€œprobably secondary to remote tobacco use with progressive airway obstruction.â€Â  The doctor asseverated, â€œI do not think this is a specific reaction to his work environment.â€Â  However, after additional testing showed Brown experienced drops â€œin his flow rates across the work shift,â€ Dr. Cobb recommended that Greenwood remove Brown from work for three months to see if his absence from the job would ameliorate his condition.Â  Brownâ€™s leave did improve his breathing.Â  As Dr. Cobb wrote in his report of June 18, 1998:

Mr. Brown feels better.Â  His exertional tolerance is slightly improved and he experiences less cough at the present time.
. . . . 
The majority of his disease is emphysema related to his previous tobacco use. . . . In addition to the emphysema from smoking, however, he does have a component of industrial related broncospasm.Â  I think this is more likely a nonspecific bronchitis than true byssinosis, but in any event, his underlying disease is exacerbated and has shown documented improvement on a period away from work and my recommendation is that he be removed from the present work space.

Brown did not work for Greenwood after 1998.Â  
On December 4, 2001, Brown was treated at a Veteransâ€™ Administration Clinic in Augusta, Georgia.Â  There, for the first time, he was diagnosed with byssinosis.Â  The report from the VA Clinic records:

Assessment:
Hypertension. Not controlled
. . . .
Hx occupational exposure to cotton dust.44years. including carding and preparation.
Bysinnosis. hx chest tightness and pre and post shift changes in spirometry (reactivity)
Hx industrial noise exposure

Brown filed a Form 50 on February 14, 2002.Â  
At the hearing, Greenwood presented the medical report of Dr. R. L. Galphin.Â  Dr. Galphin believed Brownâ€™s disease â€œwas most probably due to his long history of cigarette smoking, which may have been aggravated by exposure to respirable cotton trash dust and reactivity to that dust particularly in the latter part of his employment.â€Â  He estimated that â€œ70% of Mr. Brownâ€™s impairment is related to his long history of cigarette abuse and 30% may represent a worsening of the condition secondary to his exposure to dust in the cotton textile industry.â€Â  However, Dr. Galphin never examined Brown.Â  His opinion was based solely on a review of records from Greenwood and Dr. Cobb.Â  
The single commissioner issued an order, which stated:

After reviewing all of the evidence in the case, it is the finding of the undersigned that the claimantâ€™s respiratory disease arose out of and in the course of his employment; said disease was due to hazards of the employment which are excess of hazards normally incident to normal employees.Â  The disease is peculiar to the textile mill wherein they were running cotton products.Â  There have been numerous cases of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (byssinosis) arising out of inhalation of the organic or inorganic dust in the textile industry.Â  See, Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 SC [3]78, 335 SE2d 91 (1985)[.]Â  The hazards causing this condition are peculiar to the textile industry in which the claimant was employed for many years.Â  Based on the opinions of the doctors at the VA Clinic, it is found that the claimantâ€™s respiratory disease was a result of the exposure to cotton dust and trash in his employment.Â  The conditions of his exposure are peculiar to his employment.Â  Most particularly, his pre and post work pulmonary function studies, done by the employer, show he was having a reaction to the environment.Â  Further, the doctors at the VA Clinic opined he had severe COPD as a result of many years of textile work.

The commissioner found that the statute of limitations had not run prior to the filing of Brownâ€™s claim because he was not definitively diagnosed with byssinosis until December 4, 2001.Â  Indeed, Dr. Cobb, in 1998, had suggested, â€œthis is more likely a nonspecific bronchitis than true byssinosis,â€ and that â€œ[h]is primary disease is emphysema related to underlying previous tobacco use.â€Â  
The appellate panel affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s ruling with the following language:

In an Appellate Review, the Commission has the power to weigh the evidence as presented at the initial hearing, and, after careful review in the instant case, the Commission, by unanimous vote, has determined that all of the Hearing Commissionerâ€™s Findings of Fact and Rulings of Law are correct as stated.Â  Accordingly, they shall become, and hereby are, the law of the case; and, therefore, the Order is sustained in its entirety.Â  

Greenwood appealed to the circuit court arguing (1) the statute of limitations had run on Brownâ€™s claim, and (2) the panel erred in failing to determine the proportion of Brownâ€™s disability allocable to non-compensable causesâ€”i.e., smokingâ€”pursuant to sections 42-11-90 and â€“100 of the South Carolina Code.Â  The circuit court affirmed the panel as to the finding that the claim was within the statute of limitations, but reversed on the award of benefits:

In this case, the record is replete with evidence of the Claimantâ€™s forty-five (45) year history of smoking, a non-compensable cause, and its effect on his lungs.Â  Even if the Commission dismissed Dr. Galphinsâ€™s opinion as not being credible, Dr. Cobbâ€™s June 19, 1998 opinion that the majority of Claimantâ€™s lung disease was non-compensable cannot be ignored.Â  Indeed, the employer does have the burden of proving not only the interplay of a non-compensable cause, but also its proportion to the overall disability.Â  Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 SC 378, 335 SE2d 91 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  In this case, the employer clearly met that burden, and no substantial evidence exists in the record to support the Commissionâ€™s findings to the contrary.Â  As such, in light of the statutesâ€™ mandatory language, the employer was entitled to a determination of the proportion allocable to the non-compensable cause, smoking, and a corresponding reduction of compensation owed to the Claimant.Â  

Accordingly, the circuit court remanded the case to the commission â€œwith the specific direction to make the necessary findings as to the apportionment between compensable versus non-compensable causes, and a corresponding reduction in the Claimantâ€™s disability award.â€Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Appealability
Greenwood asserts, as a threshold matter, that the circuit courtâ€™s order remanding the case to the commission is interlocutory and not immediately appealable.Â  We disagree.
The rule governing the appealability of a circuit court order remanding a case to the commission is set forth in Montjoy v. Asten-Hill Dryer Fabrics, 316 S.C. 52, 446 S.E.2d 618 (1994):

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-390 (1986) provides:
  
An aggrieved party may obtain a review of any final judgment of the circuit court under this article by appeal to the Supreme Court.Â  The appeal shall be taken as in other civil cases.
  
Accordingly, we have consistently held that an order of the circuit court remanding a case for additional proceedings before an administrative agency is not directly appealable.Â  Owens v. Canal Wood Corp., 281 S.C. 491, 316 S.E.2d 385 (1984); Hunt v. Whitt, 279 S.C. 343, 306 S.E.2d 621 (1983).

Montjoy, 316 S.C. 52, 446 S.E.2d 618.Â  
The question here is whether the circuit court order is a â€œfinal judgmentâ€ under section 1-23-390.Â  Generally, an order is a final judgment on one or more issues if it constitutes an ultimate decision on the merits.Â  In Owens v. Canal Wood Corp., 281 S.C. 491, 316 S.E.2d 385 (1984), one of the two cases cited by the Montjoy court, the supreme court found â€œ[t]he order of the circuit court does not involve the merits of the action.Â  It is therefore interlocutory and not reviewable by this Court for lack of finality.â€Â  Owens, 281 S.C. at 492, 316 S.E.2d at 385 (emphasis added) (citations omitted).Â  Similarly, in Hunt v. Whitt, 279 S.C. 343, 306 S.E.2d 621 (1983), the supreme court held that â€œ[b]ecause the interlocutory order of the circuit court does not involve the merits of the action, it is not reviewable by this Court for lack of finality.â€Â  Id. (emphasis added) (citations omitted).Â  Accordingly, in determining whether the courtâ€™s order constitutes a final judgment, we must inquire whether the order finally decides an issue on the merits.Â  
â€œAn order involves the merits if it finally determines some substantial matter forming the whole or part of some cause of action or defense in the case.â€ Green v. City of Columbia, 311 S.C. 78, 427 S.E.2d 685 (Ct. App. 1993) (citing Henderson v. Wyatt, 8 S.C. 112 (1877)).Â  In the case sub judice, the order of the circuit court finally determined an issue on the meritsâ€”that Brownâ€™s smoking, a non-compensable cause, contributed to his disability.Â  The court noted â€œthe employer does have the burden of proving . . . the interplay of a non-compensable causeâ€ and found â€œthe employer clearly met that burden[.]â€Â  Consequently, the circuit court ruled that â€œthe employer was entitled to a determination of the proportion allocable to the non-compensable cause[.]â€Â  The case was remanded, not for evaluation whether apportionment was appropriate, but â€œwith specific direction to make the necessary findings as to the apportionment between compensable versus non-compensable causes, and a corresponding reduction in the Claimantâ€™s disability award.â€Â Â  
The courtâ€™s order mandates apportionment.Â  This ruling is a decision on the merits because it decides with finality whether Greenwood is required to reduce its compensation under sections 42-11-90 and â€“100.Â  Although the judge left the percentage of apportionment to the commission on remand, the panel would have no choice but to allocate some part of Brownâ€™s disability to the non-compensable cause.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order constitutes a final decision on the issue of apportionment and is appealable.Â  
II.Â  Statute of Limitations
Greenwood maintains that Brown filed his claim outside the period of the statute of limitations.Â  

Section 42-15-40 provides:
The right to compensation under this title is barred unless a claim is filed with the commission within two years after an accident, or if death resulted from accident, within two years of the date of death.Â  However, for occupational disease claims the two-year period does not begin to run until the employee concerned has been diagnosed definitively as having an occupational disease and has been notified of the diagnosis.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-40 (Supp. 2004) (emphasis added).Â  
In McCraw v. Mary Black Hospital, 350 S.C. 229, 565 S.E.2d 286 (2002), our supreme court proclaimed that section 42-15-40 â€œrequires that the employee be: (1) â€˜diagnosed definitively as having an occupational disease,â€™ and (2) â€˜notified of the diagnosis[.]â€™â€Â  350 S.C. at 235-36, 565 S.E.2d at 289.Â  In McCraw, Carolyn McCraw, a nurse, began experiencing breathing problems associated with handling potent chemicals in the endoscopy unit of the hospital where she was employed.Â  Dr. Applebaum, who worked with McCraw, noticed her breathing difficulties.Â  McCraw discussed her condition with Dr. Applebaum on an informal basis until September of 1991 when she transferred out of the endoscopy unit.Â  She then began seeing Dr. Applebaum, and on November 19, 1992, McCraw was admitted to the hospital for treatment of asthma and pneumonia.Â  She did not file a workersâ€™ compensation claim until November 14, 1994.Â  Although McCraw began to experience her work-induced breathing ailments more than two years before filing her claim, the supreme court found that the statute of limitations did not bar her from benefits:

Considering the record as a whole, it simply is not reasonable to conclude that Dr. Applebaumâ€™s informal conversations with McCraw in the endoscopy unit constituted a definitive diagnosis, or that McCrawâ€™s understanding her asthma was affected by the workplace chemicals somehow constitutes notification of definitive diagnosis of an occupational disease.Â  

Id. at 236, 565 S.E.2d at 289.Â Â  
Here, Brown was not definitively diagnosed as having byssinosis until his December 2001 visit to the VA Clinic.Â  Greenwood asserts that Brownâ€™s claim is barred because he understood in 1998 his deteriorated breathing condition was related to his work environment.Â  However, both the statute and precedent make clear that in an occupational disease context, the statute of limitations begins to run only upon notification of a definitive diagnosis.Â  As stated by the court in McCraw, â€œit simply is not reasonable to concludeâ€ a claimantâ€™s â€œunderstandingâ€ that his condition â€œwas affected by the workplaceâ€ environment â€œsomehow constitutes notification of definitive diagnosis of an occupational disease.â€Â  350 S.C. at 236, 565 S.E.2d at 289.Â  Brown was given a definitive diagnosis on December 4, 2001, and he filed his Form 50 on February 14, 2002.Â  Therefore, his claim is timely, and we affirm the circuit court as to the statute of limitations issue.Â  
III.Â  Allocation Under Sections 42-11-90 and â€“100 

Section 42-11-90 states:
When an occupational disease prolongs, accelerates or aggravates or is prolonged, accelerated or aggravated by any other cause or infirmity not otherwise compensable, the compensation payable for disability or death shall be limited to the disability which would have resulted solely from the occupational disease if there were no other such cause or infirmity and shall be computed by the proportion which the disability from occupational disease bears to the entire disability.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-11-90 (1985).Â  Similarly, code section 42-11-100 reads, in pertinent part,

Compensation payable for disability from an occupational disease must be the same as that provided for an injury under this title.Â  No compensation is payable: 
  
(1)Â  For the degree of disability resulting from noncompensable causes . . . . 
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-11-100 (Supp. 2004).Â  
The case sub judice is similar to Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 S.C. 378, 335 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  Charles Hanks was exposed to cotton dust for approximately fifteen years as an employee of Blair Mills.Â  In addition, he smoked a pack and a half of cigarettes a day â€œfor years.â€Â  Hanks was diagnosed with byssinosis and was awarded benefits.Â  The commission did not apportion the award under section 42-11-90, and this Court affirmed.Â  We observed:

The issue of the extent of disability is a question of fact to be proved as any other fact is proved.Â  Arnold v. Benjamin Booth Co., 257 S.C. 337, 185 S.E.2d 830 (1971).Â  This Courtâ€™s function is not to resolve conflicts in the evidence but to determine from the record if substantial evidence supports the agencyâ€™s finding. 
. . . .
The evidence revealed that Hanks had smoked a pack and a half of cigarettes a day for years and that smoking can cause or contribute to chronic obstructive lung disease.Â  Appellants, however, presented no evidence of the percentage of Hanksâ€™ disability that was caused by smoking.Â 
Mizell v. Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., 281 S.C. 430, 315 S.E.2d 123 (1984).Â  We thus find no merit in the appellantsâ€™ contention that the court should have apportioned the award based on Section 42-11-90.Â  

286 S.C. at 384-85, 335 S.E.2d at 95.Â  
In the instant case, the single commissioner was cognizant of section 42-11-90.Â  Greenwood raised the statute and the issue of allocation at the hearing, and the commissioner responded:

And in the pretrial conference you had stated your position in regards to the apportionment and I advised that I would like just a short brief, five, ten pages, on the issue of apportionment.Â  And if you would submit that to me in ten or fifteen days.Â  And Ms. McKenzie [counsel for Brown] is certainly entitled to do a brief on her position as well.

Moreover, the commissionerâ€™s order expressly finds, as a conclusion of law, 

6. Per Â§ 42-11-90, the claimant is entitled to compensation for his disability as being related to and as a result of an occupational disease resulting from cotton dust exposure. (See, Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 SC 378, 335 SE2d 91, 1985[.]

(Emphasis added.)Â  The commissionerâ€™s order concluded: 

[T]he claimantâ€™s respiratory disease arose out of and in the course of his employment; said disease was due to hazards of the employment which are excess of hazards normally incident to normal employees. . . . Based on the opinions of the doctors at the VA Clinic, it is found that the claimantâ€™s respiratory disease was a result of the exposure to cotton dust and trash in his employment.Â Â  

The linchpin of this case is the standard by which we must review factual determinations of the commission. The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the workersâ€™ compensation commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981); Bass v. Isochem, ___S.C.___, 617 S.E.2d 369 (Ct. App. 2005); Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 599 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify a decision of an agency if the findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions of that agency are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â 
Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health &
Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the appellate panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Liberty
Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 611 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2005); Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 593 S.E.2d 491 (Ct. App. 2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) (2005).
The substantial evidence rule of the APA governs the standard of review in a workersâ€™ compensation decision.Â  Frame, 357 S.C. at 527, 593 S.E.2d at 494; Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 571 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Lockridge v. Santens of America, Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œAny review of the commissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€).Â  Pursuant to the APA, this Courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the appellate panelâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  See Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 610 S.E.2d 488 (2005); Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 526 S.E.2d 725 (Ct. App. 2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005); see also Grant v. Grant Textiles, 361 S.C. 188, 191, 603 S.E.2d 858, 859 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œA reviewing court will not overturn a decision by the workersâ€™ compensation commission unless the determination is unsupported by substantial evidence or is affected by an error of law.â€); Lyles v. Quantum Chem. Co. (Emery), 315 S.C. 440, 434 S.E.2d 292 (Ct. App. 1993) (noting that in reviewing decision of workersâ€™ compensation commission, court of appeals will not set aside its findings unless they are not supported by substantial evidence or they are controlled by error of law).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 272 (2004); Jones v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 586 S.E.2d 111 (2003); Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 562 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 2002); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 520 S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999).
The appellate panel is the ultimate fact finder in workersâ€™ compensation cases and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729; Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the appellate panel.Â 
Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000); Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 (1995); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495; Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 102 (1999); DuRant v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health &
Envtl. Control, 361 S.C. 416, 604 S.E.2d 704 (Ct. App. 2004); Corbin, 351 S.C. at 618, 571 S.E.2d at 95; Muir, 336 S.C. at 282, 519 S.E.2d at 591.Â  Where there are conflicts in the evidence over a factual issue, the findings of the appellate panel are conclusive.Â  Hargrove, 360 S.C. at 290, 599 S.E.2d at 611; Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 455, 562 S.E.2d at 681.
The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001); Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 515 S.E.2d 532 (1999); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495.Â  It is not within our province to reverse findings of the appellate panel which are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Pratt, 357 S.C. at 622, 594 S.E.2d at 274-75; Broughton, 336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 637.
The parties presented the commissioner with conflicting medical opinion evidence as to the cause of Brownâ€™s disability.Â  Whether a history of cigarette smoking was a causal factor in Brownâ€™s disease was a factual question which the commissioner and the commission answered in the negative.Â  The commissioner noted that byssinosis is a condition peculiarly associated with cotton dust exposure.Â  Additionally, Brown stopped smoking in 1995, yet his condition worsened between 1995 and 1998.Â  Tests demonstrated that his work environment negatively affected Brownâ€™s breathing.Â  Finally, the opinion of the doctor from the VA Clinic, the only doctor to definitively diagnose Brown with byssinosis, stated that Brownâ€™s condition was the result of forty-four years of exposure to cotton dust.
Although the circuit court might have ruled differently had it been the fact finder, it was error for the court to substitute its factual judgment in place of the commissionâ€™s.Â  As we observed in Stone v. Traylor Brothers, Inc., 360 S.C. 271, 600 S.E.2d 551 (Ct. App. 2004), â€œAdmittedly, the Commission could have reached a different conclusion.Â  However, that fact does not alter the scope of our inquiry.â€Â  Id. (citing Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub.
Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984) (â€œ[The] possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€)).Â  
Based on the evidence presented, reasonable minds could conclude Brownâ€™s byssinosis is the result of his exposure to cotton dust without regard to his history of smoking.Â  The commission, aware of the apportionment statutes, made a factual determination which is supported by substantial evidence.Â  Accordingly, that portion of the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the commissionâ€™s ruling on section 42-11-90 is reversed and the commissionâ€™s award of benefits is reinstated.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the circuit court is affirmed in part and reversed in part, and the commissionâ€™s order is reinstated.
 AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

description: In this criminal matter, the appellant appeals her conviction for murder.  She contends the trial court erred in (1) refusing to allow her to impeach one of the State's witnesses, the deceased's wife, with evidence that the witness expressed fear of the deceased after a domestic dispute, when the witness denied she was ever afraid of the victim; (2) refusing to allow evidence appellant was aware of the deceased's prior act of violence against the wife and the wife's property as this was relevant to appellant's claim of self-defense; and (3) refusing to instruct the jury on the law of involuntary manslaughter based on appellant's self-defense theory, where there was evidence appellant armed herself in self-defense but discharged the gun due to her reckless handling of the weapon.

  admissible unless they were directed against the defendant or, if directed
  against others, were so closely connected at point of time or occasion with the
  homicide as reasonably to indicate the state of mind of the deceased at the
  time of the homicide, or to produce reasonable apprehension of great bodily
  harm.â€Â  Id. at 419-20, 535 S.E.2d at 436.Â  The court noted that the
  prior act of violence against Szumowicz occurred only four months prior to
  Renewâ€™s death, and held the evidence was admissible to prove Day had a
  reasonable apprehension of violence from Renew, an essential element of his
self-defense claim.Â  Id. at 421, 535 S.E.2d at 437.
In the
  case at hand, the prior act of violence by Bubba against Robette occurred less
  than three months prior to Bubbaâ€™s death and was so closely connected at point
  of time to indicate Bubbaâ€™s state of mind at the time of the shooting.Â  The
  prior incident of criminal domestic violence was also admissible to prove
  Mekler had a reasonable apprehension of great bodily harm from Bubba, an
  essential element of Meklerâ€™s claim of self-defense as well as her claim of
defense of others. 
III. Failure to charge the jury on the law of involuntary manslaughter
Mekler finally
  contends the trial judge erred in refusing to instruct the jury on involuntary
  manslaughter.Â  We agree.
At
  the close of the evidence, defense counsel requested a jury instruction on
  involuntary manslaughter.Â  The trial judge found there was a strong inference
  from Meklerâ€™s testimony that she â€œcertainly intended to shoot [Bubba].â€Â  He
  noted Mekler said she was afraid of Bubba and was protecting herself and quoted
  Mekler as saying, â€œI meant to stop him.â€Â  The trial judge thus determined
  involuntary manslaughter would be an inappropriate charge based on what he
  â€œperceive[d] to be self-defense.â€Â  
The
  law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.Â  State
    v. Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 51, 584 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2003).Â  A trial court
  should refuse to charge a lesser-included offense only where there is no
  evidence the defendant committed the lesser rather than the greater offense.Â  State
    v. Chatman, 336 S.C. 149, 152, 519 S.E.2d 100, 101 (1999).Â  Stated another
  way, if there is any evidence from which the jury could infer the defendant
  committed a lesser rather than a greater offense, the trial judge must charge
  the lesser-included offense.Â  State v. White, 361 S.C. 407, 412, 605
  S.E.2d 540, 542 (2004).Â  
Involuntary
  manslaughter is (1) the unintentional killing of another without malice, but
  while engaged in an unlawful activity not naturally tending to cause death or
  great bodily harm;Â  or (2) the unintentional killing of another without malice,
  while engaged in a lawful activity with reckless disregard for the safety of
  others.Â  Chatman, 336 S.C. at 152, 519 S.E.2d at 101.Â  A person can be
  acting lawfully, even if he is in unlawful possession of a weapon, if he was
  entitled to arm himself in self-defense at the time of the shooting.Â  Crosby, 355 S.C. at 52, 584 S.E.2d at 112;Â  State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256,
  262, 513 S.E.2d 104, 108 (1999).Â  The negligent handling of a gun can support a
  finding of involuntary manslaughter.Â  Burriss, 334 S.C. at 265, 513
  S.E.2d at 109.
Here,
  there is evidence that would support a finding Mekler was lawfully armed in
  self-defense at the time of the fatal shooting.Â  Further, there is ample
  evidence from which the jury could infer Mekler did not intentionally discharge
  the shotgun.Â  Although Mekler stated on cross-examination that she had cocked
  the gun and â€œmeant for [Bubba] to stop,â€ she clearly testified on direct that,
  as she was cocking the gun, Bubba leaned to the right â€œand the gun fired.â€Â 
  Mekler specifically testified she did not remember pulling the trigger.Â  Mekler
  also consistently maintained in her statements to police that she did not
  remember pulling the trigger.Â  In her detailed statement taken at the Sheriffâ€™s
  Office, Mekler stated she was not trying to shoot Bubba, and did not mean for
  the gun to fire. She indicated when the gun went off, it shocked her.Â  Mekler
  also consistently stated that when Robette told Mekler she had shot Bubba,
  Mekler replied in disbelief that she had not.Â  She further testified during
  cross-examination that her finger must have slipped â€œand got on the trigger,â€
  and that she did not remember pulling the trigger.Â  
In Crosby,
  the facts showed Crosby was involved in an incident with a group of people when
  the victim began charging at Crosby with his hand behind his back.Â  Crosby indicated that he pulled out a gun, closed eyes and pulled the trigger, but he did
  not know he pulled the trigger.Â  Crosby, 355 S.C. at 50, 584 S.E.2d at
  111.Â  Our Supreme Court found, in spite of Crosbyâ€™s admission that he closed
  his eyes and pulled the trigger, Crosby immediately added that he did not even
  know that he pulled the trigger.Â  The fact that there may have been evidence
  showing the shooting was intentional did not negate the other inferences that
  could be drawn from all the evidence.Â  Thus, the court found Crosby was
  entitled to a jury charge on the law of involuntary manslaughter.Â  Id. at 53, 584 S.E.2d at 112-13.Â Â Â  
We
  likewise hold, given the evidence adduced at trial, Mekler was entitled to have
  the jury charged on the law of involuntary manslaughter.Â  Because there is
  evidence from which the jury could have inferred Mekler did not intentionally
  discharge the shotgun, the trial judge erroneously concluded an involuntary
  manslaughter charge was precluded by Meklerâ€™s self-defense claim.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the trial judge
  erred in excluding testimony of the past violent act by Bubba that was closely
  related in time and occasion to the shooting death of Bubba.Â  We further hold
  the trial judge erred in failing to instruct the jury on the law of involuntary
  manslaughter.Â  For the foregoing reasons, Meklerâ€™s murder conviction isÂ Â  
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON
and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1]After the initial statement to the first officer on
  the scene, Mekler was advised of her rights before any further statements were
  given by her, and there is no issue as to the voluntariness of any of her
statements.Â  
[2]This rule provides, â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may
  be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of
  unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by
  considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of
cumulative evidence.â€
